  <main lang="en" id="main-content" role="main" aria-label="2015-09 PRESS RELEASE - DBMI and NCATS to Collaborate on Global Rare Diseases Data Repository" aria-labelledby="page-title" tabindex="-1">
    <div class="layout-content">
        <div>
    <div data-drupal-messages-fallback class="hidden"></div>

<article lang="en" class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full">
  <div  class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
  <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
    
    <h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
      <span>2015-09 PRESS RELEASE - DBMI and NCATS to Collaborate on Global Rare Diseases Data Repository</span>

    </h1>
    
     </div>
</div>

        <div
      class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64 ">
            <div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
                  
            <div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>In August 2015, the National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences (NCATS) awarded DBMI a supplemental grant of $2.4M to further develop the Global Rare Diseases Patient Registry Data Repository/GRDR&nbsp;program.&nbsp;</p><p></p><p><a href="http://dbmi.hms.harvard.edu/news/dbmi-and-ncats-collaborate-global-rare-diseases-data-repository">http://dbmi.hms.harvard.edu/news/dbmi-and-ncats-collaborate-global-rare-diseases-data-repository</a></p><p><a href="http://ncats.nih.gov/grdr">http://ncats.nih.gov/grdr</a></p><p></p><p><br><br></p><p></p></div>
      
        
        
              </div>
    </div>
  
  </article>

  </div>

    </div>
    
      </main>

                                              </div>
        </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hwp-mt-32 lg:hwp-w-2/3 xl:hwp-w-3/4 lg:hwp-mt-0 lg:hwp-flex lg:hwp-flex-col">

            <a href="/login" class="hwp-py-8 hwp-mt-16 hwp-inline-flex">Admin login</a>
          </div>
              </div>
    </div>
  </div>

    <h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
      <span>2015-11 KEYNOTE - tranSMART Foundation Annual Meeting -  Creating Trust in Translational Research Platforms</span>

    </h1>
    
     </div>
</div>

            <div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
                  
            <div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>Paul Avillach's presentation at tranSMART Foundation Annual Meeting, Amsterdam, Netherlands, November 2015</p><p>YouTube: <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y8Eqsr571C8">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y8Eqsr571C8</a></p><p>Content: <a href="http://lanyrd.com/2015/transmart-foundation-annual-meeting/sdrzqg/">http://lanyrd.com/2015/transmart-foundation-annual-meeting/sdrzqg/</a></p><p></p></div>

  <main lang="en" id="main-content" role="main" aria-label="2016-10 Splunk Revolution Awards" aria-labelledby="page-title" tabindex="-1">
    <div class="layout-content">
        <div>
    <div data-drupal-messages-fallback class="hidden"></div>

<article lang="en" class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full">
  <div  class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
  <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
    
    <h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
      <span>2016-10 Splunk Revolution Awards</span>

    </h1>
    
     </div>
</div>

        <div
      class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64 ">
            <div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
                  
            <div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>Paul Avillach, MD, PhD - Splunk Innovation Award Winner 2016</p><p>The Splunk&nbsp;Innovation Award recognizes customers who have used the Splunk platform to solve a unique problem within their organizations, uncovered new business opportunities and revenue streams, or developed or integrated a new app into a cross-platform solution.</p><p><a href="http://blogs.splunk.com/2016/10/28/meet-the-2016-splunk-revolution-award-winners/">http://blogs.splunk.com/2016/10/28/meet-the-2016-splunk-revolution-award-winners/</a></p></div>
      
        
        
              </div>
    </div>
  
  </article>

  </div>

    </div>
    
      </main>

    </div>
  </nav>

<article lang="en" class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full">
  <div  class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
  <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
    
    <h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
      <span>Contact us</span>

    </h1>
    
     </div>
</div>

        <div
      class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64 ">
            <div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
                  
        
                  
      <div class="field field--name-field-hwp-additional-content field--type-entity-reference-revisions field--label-hidden">
              <div class="paragraphs-item__first paragraphs-item">
<div  class="hwp-text-block hwp-bg-light-core hwp-py-32">
  <div class="hwp-container-px hwp-container">    
        
            
            <div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><div class="align-left hwp-media hwp-media--medium">
  
  
            <div class="field field--name-field-media-image field--type-image field--label-hidden">    <picture>
                  <source srcset="/sites/g/files/omnuum4001/files/styles/hwp_1_1__720x720_scale/public/avillach_lab/files/countway.jpg?itok=pNmXJC8V 1x, /sites/g/files/omnuum4001/files/styles/hwp_1_1__1440x1440_scale/public/avillach_lab/files/countway.jpg?itok=3WmOajQa 2x" media="all and (min-width: 0)" type="image/jpeg" width="200" height="150">
                  <img loading="eager" width="200" height="150" src="/sites/g/files/omnuum4001/files/styles/hwp_1_1__720x720_scale/public/avillach_lab/files/countway.jpg?itok=pNmXJC8V" alt="countway.jpg">

  </picture>

</div>
      
</div>
<p><strong>Avillach Lab</strong><br>Department of Biomedical Informatics<br>10 Shattuck St, 4th Floor<br>Boston, MA 02115<br><a href="mailto:paul_avillach@hms.harvard.edu">paul_avillach@hms.harvard.edu</a></p></div>
      
    </div></div>
</div>
              <div class="paragraphs-item">
<div  class="hwp-text-block hwp-bg-light-core hwp-py-32">
  <div class="hwp-container-px hwp-container">    
        
            
            <div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p><strong>To the Longwood Medical Area:</strong></p><p>* If you're coming by the T, Green Lines D ("Longwood" stop) and E ("Longwood Medical Area" stop) are 2-3 blocks away.<br>* From the Harvard main campus, take the LMA (Longwood Medical Area) M2 shuttle (click <a href="http://www.masco.org/transit/ptsM2.htm">here</a> for schedule). A Harvard ID is required. You can catch the bus by Lamont Library; it takes 15-25 minutes depending on traffic.<br>* From MIT, you can take the Crosstown bus (CT2) (click <a href="http://www.mbta.com/traveling_t/schedules_buses_findbus.asp?routenumber=CT2&amp;imageField2.x=60&amp;imageField2.y=14">here</a> for route and schedule).</p></div>
      
    </div></div>
</div>
              <div class="paragraphs-item">
<div  class="hwp-text-block hwp-bg-light-core hwp-py-32">
  <div class="hwp-container-px hwp-container">    
        
            
            <div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p><strong>Entry to the Building:</strong></p><p>* <strong>Countway</strong>: A Harvard, MIT, or a hospital ID is needed. (If you do not have it, please speak to the guard and explain that you are visitor. A call to my office may be needed). The Library is located next to the Gordon Hall in the main Quad (you can see the top of the library between the buildings):</p><div class="hwp-media hwp-media--medium">
  
  
            <div class="field field--name-field-media-image field--type-image field--label-hidden">    <picture>
                  <source srcset="/sites/g/files/omnuum4001/files/styles/hwp_1_1__720x720_scale/public/avillach_lab/files/rsch_sci_env_quad_0.jpg?itok=UNR3Oav6 1x, /sites/g/files/omnuum4001/files/styles/hwp_1_1__1440x1440_scale/public/avillach_lab/files/rsch_sci_env_quad_0.jpg?itok=SBwxDP92 2x" media="all and (min-width: 0)" type="image/jpeg" width="508" height="270">
                  <img loading="eager" width="508" height="270" src="/sites/g/files/omnuum4001/files/styles/hwp_1_1__720x720_scale/public/avillach_lab/files/rsch_sci_env_quad_0.jpg?itok=UNR3Oav6" alt="rsch_sci_env_quad_0.jpg">

  </picture>

</div>
      
</div>
</div>
      
    </div></div>
</div>
              <div class="paragraphs-item__last paragraphs-item">
<div  class="hwp-text-block hwp-bg-light-core hwp-py-32">
  <div class="hwp-container-px hwp-container">    
        
            
            <div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p><strong>Map of the Longwood Medical Area (Click&nbsp;</strong><a href="https://prod-avillachlab.drupalsites.harvard.edu/sites/g/files/omnuum4001/files/avillach_lab/files/longwoodmap.pdf"><strong>here</strong></a><strong> for the pdf map)</strong></p><div class="hwp-media hwp-media--medium">
  
  
            <div class="field field--name-field-media-image field--type-image field--label-hidden">    <picture>
                  <source srcset="/sites/g/files/omnuum4001/files/styles/hwp_1_1__720x720_scale/public/avillach_lab/files/longwoodmap.gif?itok=rWIfPa1h 1x, /sites/g/files/omnuum4001/files/styles/hwp_1_1__1440x1440_scale/public/avillach_lab/files/longwoodmap.gif?itok=Is4PFdii 2x" media="all and (min-width: 0)" type="image/gif" width="720" height="562">
                  <img loading="eager" width="720" height="562" src="/sites/g/files/omnuum4001/files/styles/hwp_1_1__720x720_scale/public/avillach_lab/files/longwoodmap.gif?itok=rWIfPa1h" alt="longwoodmap.gif">

  </picture>

</div>
      
</div>
</div>
      
    </div></div>

  <div  class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
  <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
    
    <h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
      <span>Autism Pilot</span>

    </h1>
    
     </div>
</div>

        <div
      class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64 ">
            <div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
                  
            <div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>	BCH internally-funded Gene partnership / Research Connection</p><p>	Co-Investigator ($800k) (PI: Isaac Kohane)</p><p>	Creating a comprehensive autism clinical and genomic database using an i2b2-based research platform: tranSMART</p></div>
      
        
        
                  

<div class="hwp-news-footer hwp-py-24 hwp-pt-0 hwp-container hwp-container-px">

<!-- Source: avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu -->
<h1>Avillach Lab | Avillach Lab</h1>
<div class='source-url'><a href='https://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu'>avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu</a></div>
<main aria-label="Avillach Lab" aria-labelledby="page-title" id="main-content" lang="en" role="main" tabindex="-1">
<div class="layout-content">
<div>
<div class="hidden" data-drupal-messages-fallback=""></div>
<article class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base hwp-sr-only">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
<h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
<span>Avillach Lab</span>
</h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
<div class="field field--name-field-hwp-additional-content field--type-entity-reference-revisions field--label-hidden">
<div class="paragraphs-item__first paragraphs-item">
<div class="hwp-text-block hwp-bg-light-core hwp-py-32">
<div class="hwp-container-px hwp-container">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><h2>Welcome to Avillach Lab at the <a href="https://cbmi.med.harvard.edu">Department of Biomedical Informatics</a></h2><p><strong>The real value in biomedical research lies not at the scale of any single source of data but in the ability to integrate and interrogate multiple complementary datasets simultaneously.</strong></p><p dir="ltr">The Avillach Lab, led by <a data-entity-substitution="canonical" data-entity-type="node" data-entity-uuid="d7b96fd9-1e1b-403e-a097-7e636b911581" href="/people/paul-avillach-md-phd" title="Paul Avillach, MD, PhD">Paul Avillach, M.D., Ph.D.</a>,Â  focuses on translational bioinformatics, specifically in integrating multiple heterogeneous sources of clinical and genomic data in a meaningful way. We are passionate about combining data across different scales and resolutions to enable new perspectives for essential biomedical questions. Our research focuses on developing novel methods and techniques for the integration of biological data, clinical cohorts, and Electronic Health Records to encompass biological observations.</p><p dir="ltr">We leverage the PIC-SURE (Patient-centered Information Commons: Standardized Unification of Research Elements) platform to manage a wide variety of arbitrarily large datasets with very little computing in a secured way by searching and extracting clinical and genomic variables of interest. Exposing the data not only at the file level but also at the variable and variant level directly accelerates creation of statistically ready dataframes. PIC-SURE has been deployed in a variety of environments, such as the NIH NHLBI BioData CatalystÂ® Ecosystem, the Undiagnosed Disease Network, and Boston Childrenâs Hospital (see <a data-entity-substitution="canonical" data-entity-type="node" data-entity-uuid="e41c2647-f3b6-4a46-a5e8-f8504d568a91" href="/research" title="Research &amp; Collaborations">research</a>).</p><figure class="hwp-media hwp-media--full-width" role="group">
<div>
<div class="field field--name-field-media-image field--type-image field--label-hidden"> <img alt="A person's data consists of many &quot;layers&quot; or data types" height="500" loading="lazy" src="/sites/g/files/omnuum4001/files/avillach_lab/files/home2.png" width="1000"/>
</div>
</div>
<figcaption><strong>Figure depicting various, interconnected âlayersâ of clinical and genomic data.</strong></figcaption>
</figure>
<p>PIC-SURE contains both a graphical user interface (UI) and an application programming interface (API). With the UI, researchers can test their hypotheses by running multi-criteria queries at both the file- and variable-levels and applying distinct clinical and genomic variable filters in the same search. With the API, users can filter and directly retrieve the data in an analysis-ready format using either R or Python.Â </p><p>Â </p></div>
</div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</article>
</div>
</div>
</main><hr>
<!-- Source: avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/courses-0 -->

<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
<h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
<span>Contact us</span>
</h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
<div class="field field--name-field-hwp-additional-content field--type-entity-reference-revisions field--label-hidden">
<div class="paragraphs-item__first paragraphs-item">
<div class="hwp-text-block hwp-bg-light-core hwp-py-32">
<div class="hwp-container-px hwp-container">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><div class="align-left hwp-media hwp-media--medium">
<div class="field field--name-field-media-image field--type-image field--label-hidden"> <picture>
<source height="150" media="all and (min-width: 0)" srcset="/sites/g/files/omnuum4001/files/styles/hwp_1_1__720x720_scale/public/avillach_lab/files/countway.jpg?itok=pNmXJC8V 1x, /sites/g/files/omnuum4001/files/styles/hwp_1_1__1440x1440_scale/public/avillach_lab/files/countway.jpg?itok=3WmOajQa 2x" type="image/jpeg" width="200"/>
<img alt="countway.jpg" height="150" loading="eager" src="/sites/g/files/omnuum4001/files/styles/hwp_1_1__720x720_scale/public/avillach_lab/files/countway.jpg?itok=pNmXJC8V" width="200"/>
</picture>
</div>
</div>
<p><strong>Avillach Lab</strong><br/>Department of Biomedical Informatics<br/>10 Shattuck St, 4th Floor<br/>Boston, MA 02115<br/><a href="mailto:paul_avillach@hms.harvard.edu">paul_avillach@hms.harvard.edu</a></p></div>
</div></div>
</div>
<div class="paragraphs-item">
<div class="hwp-text-block hwp-bg-light-core hwp-py-32">
<div class="hwp-container-px hwp-container">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p><strong>To the Longwood Medical Area:</strong></p><p>* If you're coming by the T, Green Lines D ("Longwood" stop) and E ("Longwood Medical Area" stop) are 2-3 blocks away.<br/>* From the Harvard main campus, take the LMA (Longwood Medical Area) M2 shuttle (click <a href="http://www.masco.org/transit/ptsM2.htm">here</a> for schedule). A Harvard ID is required. You can catch the bus by Lamont Library; it takes 15-25 minutes depending on traffic.<br/>* From MIT, you can take the Crosstown bus (CT2) (click <a href="http://www.mbta.com/traveling_t/schedules_buses_findbus.asp?routenumber=CT2&amp;imageField2.x=60&amp;imageField2.y=14">here</a> for route and schedule).</p></div>
</div></div>
</div>
<div class="paragraphs-item">
<div class="hwp-text-block hwp-bg-light-core hwp-py-32">
<div class="hwp-container-px hwp-container">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p><strong>Entry to the Building:</strong></p><p>* <strong>Countway</strong>: A Harvard, MIT, or a hospital ID is needed. (If you do not have it, please speak to the guard and explain that you are visitor. A call to my office may be needed). The Library is located next to the Gordon Hall in the main Quad (you can see the top of the library between the buildings):</p><div class="hwp-media hwp-media--medium">
<div class="field field--name-field-media-image field--type-image field--label-hidden"> <picture>

</picture>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>

<!-- Source: avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/pic-sure -->
<h1>PIC-SURE | Avillach Lab</h1>
<div class='source-url'><a href='https://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/pic-sure'>avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/pic-sure</a></div>
<main aria-label="PIC-SURE" aria-labelledby="page-title" id="main-content" lang="en" role="main" tabindex="-1">
<div class="layout-content">
<div>
<div class="hidden" data-drupal-messages-fallback=""></div>
<article class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
<h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
<span>PIC-SURE</span>
</h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><h2>Introduction to PIC-SURE</h2><p dir="ltr"><span>The Patient-centered Information Commons: Standard Unification of Research Elements (PIC-SURE) platform integrates different layers of clinical and genomic data from diverse data sources, providing a multifaceted approach to biomedical research.Â </span></p><p dir="ltr"><span>The PIC-SURE platform was built on </span><a href="https://www.i2b2.org/"><span>Informatics for Integrating Biology &amp; the Bedside (i2b2)</span></a><span>, a data model created for electronic health record data. PIC-SURE is developed with an open-source Apache 2.0 license and deployed in Federal Information Security Modernization Act (FISMA) Moderate ATO and HI-TRUST environments.</span></p><p dir="ltr">Â </p><h2><span>Features of PIC-SURE</span></h2><h3><span>User Interface and Application Programming Interface</span></h3><p><span>The PIC-SURE platform provides both an intuitive graphical user interface (UI) and an application programming interface (API) to meet different use cases and levels of experience with data manipulation. The PIC-SURE UI allows for an investigator to search for variables of interest and to conduct feasibility queries. In this way, cohorts are built in real-time and results can be retrieved for analysis.Â </span></p><h3><span>Query Builder</span></h3><p><span>The Query Builder in the PIC-SURE UI allows users to interactively build queries and returns the counts of participants that meet the criteria. This tool functions similarly to a search engine, providing the ability to search a term of interest and returning variables that contain the search term. After determining a variable of interest, users can refine their query to filter participants with certain values and build a cohort. Both single and multiple criteria queries are supported.</span></p><h3><span>GitHub</span></h3><p dir="ltr"><span>PIC-SURE is developed under an Apache 2.0 license; all code is open source and accessible on the </span><a href="https://github.com/hms-dbmi/pic-sure-all-in-one"><span>PIC-SURE All-in-one GitHub repository</span></a><span>. Â Â </span></p><p dir="ltr"><span>For users interested in the PIC-SURE API, several Jupyter notebooks (R and Python) and R Markdown files contain coding examples for key PIC-SURE use cases. These examples provide a starting point for users to get started with their own analyses and are publicly available on the </span><a href="https://github.com/hms-dbmi/Access-to-Data-using-PIC-SURE-API"><span>Access to Data Using PIC-SURE API GitHub Repository</span></a><span>. Â </span></p><p dir="ltr">Â </p><h2><span>Training Materials</span></h2><h3><span>DocumentationÂ </span></h3><p><span>Written documentation for PIC-SURE can be found on the </span><a href="https://pic-sure.gitbook.io/pic-sure"><span>PIC-SURE Gitbook documentation</span></a><span>. Â Â </span></p><h3><span>VideosÂ </span></h3><p>The <a href="https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCIfahDUjW4A4B1KyIek4YJA">PIC-SURE YouTube channel</a> has video demonstrations of PIC-SURE features such as searching, filtering, and building cohorts. Researchers can find videos specific to certain PIC-SURE environments by <a href="https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCIfahDUjW4A4B1KyIek4YJA/playlists">viewing the playlists</a>.</p><p>Â </p><h2>PIC-SURE Instances</h2><h3>Demo PIC-SURE</h3><p>The demonstration site of PIC-SURE allows users to access the <a href="https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/nhanes/index.html">National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) dataset</a>. You can submit a request to access the site by emailing <a href="mailto:avillach_lab_developers@googlegroups.com">avillach_lab_developers@googlegroups.com</a>.Â </p><h3>NHLBI BioData CatalystÂ®</h3><p>The National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute BioData CatalystÂ® (BDC) is a cloud-based ecosystem that offers researchers data, analytic tools, applications, and workflows in secure workspaces.Â </p><p><a href="https://picsure.biodatacatalyst.nhlbi.nih.gov/">BDC Powered by PIC-SURE</a> is available to search hosted heart, lung, blood, and sleep data publicly.Â </p><h3>Genomic Information CommonsÂ </h3><p>The Genomic Information Commons (GIC) is a continuously updating, queryable, federated genomic data commons. <span>Inspired by a common vision of accelerated genomic research discovery, collaboration, and improved clinical outcomes, leaders at Boston Childrenâs Hospital (BCH), Harvard Medical School, Cincinnati Childrenâs Hospital Medical Center (CCHMC), the Childrenâs Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP), St. Louis Childrenâs Hospital (SLCH)/Washington University at St. Louis (WUSTL), and the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center (UPMC) have come together to create the GIC.</span></p><p><span>The GIC is available to those in the GIC consortium. You can learn more at the </span><a href="https://www.genomicinformationcommons.org/"><span>GIC website</span></a><span>.Â </span></p><h3>AIM-AHEAD</h3><p>The National Institute of Health's AIM-AHEAD program has established mutually beneficial, coordinated, and trusted partnerships to enhance the participation and representation of researchers and communities currently under-resourced in the development of artificial intelligence and machine learning models and to improve the capabilities of this emerging technology, beginning with electronic health records (EHR) and extending to other data sets to address health inconsistencies.Â </p><p>To learn more, please refer to the <a href="https://www.aim-ahead.net/">AIM-AHEAD website</a>.Â </p></div>
</div>
</div>
</article>
</div>
</div>

<div class="hwp-citations-group">
<h3 class="h3 hwp-mb-24">2025</h3>
<div class="hwp-citations-group__inner">
<div class="hwp-citation hwp-citation--text-additional hwp-bg-light-base js-hwp-citation bibcite-reference" data-component-name="citation" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-citation__text">
<div class="hwp-text-block__default-text">
<div class="bibcite-citation">
<div class="csl-bib-body"><div class="csl-entry"><div class="csl-left-margin">Alkuraya I, Almansa AS, Eleonu A, Avillach P, Poduri A, Srivastava S. <a href="/publication/use-computational-phenotypes-predicting-genetic-subgroups-cerebral-palsy">Use of Computational Phenotypes for Predicting Genetic Subgroups of Cerebral Palsy.</a>.</div><div class="csl-right-inline">medRxiv : the preprint server for health sciences. 2025; PMID: 39990554</div></div></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-text-block">
<div class="bibcite-citation">
<div class="csl-bib-body"><div class="csl-entry"><div class="csl-left-margin">Alkuraya I, Almansa AS, Eleonu A, Avillach P, Poduri A, Srivastava S. <a href="/publication/use-computational-phenotypes-predicting-genetic-subgroups-cerebral-palsy">Use of Computational Phenotypes for Predicting Genetic Subgroups of Cerebral Palsy.</a>.</div><div class="csl-right-inline">medRxiv : the preprint server for health sciences. 2025; PMID: 39990554</div></div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<ul class="hwp-citation__ctas">
<li class="expand-button-wrap">
<button aria-controls="hwp-citation-body-content-983783844" aria-expanded="false" class="hwp-text-link hwp-text-link--icon-left hwp-citation__full-body-expand js-hwp-citation__full-body-expand">
<span aria-hidden="true" class="material-icon material-icon--show">add_circle</span>
<span aria-hidden="true" class="material-icon material-icon--hide">do_not_disturb_on</span>
<span class="hwp-text-link__text">Abstract</span>
</button>
</li>
</ul>
<div aria-hidden="true" class="hwp-citation__full-body" id="hwp-citation-body-content-983783844">
<div class="hwp-text-block">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-bibcite-abst-e field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>INTRODUCTION: Emerging evidence suggests that 20-30% of cases of cerebral palsy (CP) may have a genetic cause. Our group previously identified subsets of patients with CP or CP-masquerading conditions who warrant genetic testing, including those with regression or progressive neurological symptoms (CP masqueraders) and those without any known risk factors for CP (cryptogenic CP). Recognition of these subgroups in clinical settings remains challenging.</p><p>METHODS: To address this challenge, we developed and evaluated a computational phenotyping approach using ICD- 9/ICD-10 billing codes to automatically identify patients with unexplained CP or CP-masquerading conditions who may benefit from genetic testing. We applied this computational phenotyping approach to a cohort of 250 participants from the Boston Children's Hospital CP Sequencing Study, aimed at identifying genetic causes in CP and CP-masquerading conditions.</p><p>RESULTS: Manual review served as the gold standard, identifying 8% as CP masqueraders, 42% as cryptogenic CP, and 50% as non-cryptogenic CP. Computational phenotyping based on ICD-9/10 codes achieved a sensitivity of 95%, specificity of 72%, positive predictive value of 77%, and negative predictive value of 94% in identifying cases warranting genetic testing.</p><p>CONCLUSIONS: Our findings demonstrate the feasibility of using computational phenotyping to identify patients with CP or CP- masquerading conditions who warrant genetic testing. Further studies are needed to evaluate the effectiveness and real-world application of this tool in larger healthcare systems. Nonetheless, the computational phenotyping approach holds promise as a possible clinical decision support that could be integrated into electronic health record systems, enhancing clinical workflows and facilitating actionable genetic diagnoses.</p></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-citation hwp-citation--text-additional hwp-bg-light-base js-hwp-citation bibcite-reference" data-component-name="citation" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-citation__text">
<div class="hwp-text-block__default-text">
<div class="bibcite-citation">
<div class="csl-bib-body"><div class="csl-entry"><div class="csl-left-margin">Yang D, Zhou D, Cai S, Gan Z, Pencina M, Avillach P, Cai T, Hong C. <a href="/publication/robust-automated-harmonization-heterogeneous-data-through-ensemble-machine-learning">Robust Automated Harmonization of Heterogeneous Data Through Ensemble Machine Learning: Algorithm Development and Validation Study.</a>.</div><div class="csl-right-inline">JMIR medical informatics. 2025;13:e54133. PMID: 39844378</div></div></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-text-block">
<div class="bibcite-citation">
<div class="csl-bib-body"><div class="csl-entry"><div class="csl-left-margin">Yang D, Zhou D, Cai S, Gan Z, Pencina M, Avillach P, Cai T, Hong C. <a href="/publication/robust-automated-harmonization-heterogeneous-data-through-ensemble-machine-learning">Robust Automated Harmonization of Heterogeneous Data Through Ensemble Machine Learning: Algorithm Development and Validation Study.</a>.</div><div class="csl-right-inline">JMIR medical informatics. 2025;13:e54133. PMID: 39844378</div></div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<ul class="hwp-citation__ctas">
<li class="expand-button-wrap">
<button aria-controls="hwp-citation-body-content-1907437921" aria-expanded="false" class="hwp-text-link hwp-text-link--icon-left hwp-citation__full-body-expand js-hwp-citation__full-body-expand">
<span aria-hidden="true" class="material-icon material-icon--show">add_circle</span>
<span aria-hidden="true" class="material-icon material-icon--hide">do_not_disturb_on</span>
<span class="hwp-text-link__text">Abstract</span>
</button>
</li>
</ul>
<div aria-hidden="true" class="hwp-citation__full-body" id="hwp-citation-body-content-1907437921">
<div class="hwp-text-block">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-bibcite-abst-e field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>BACKGROUND: Cohort studies contain rich clinical data across large and diverse patient populations and are a common source of observational data for clinical research. Because large scale cohort studies are both time and resource intensive, one alternative is to harmonize data from existing cohorts through multicohort studies. However, given differences in variable encoding, accurate variable harmonization is difficult.</p><p>OBJECTIVE: We propose SONAR (Semantic and Distribution-Based Harmonization) as a method for harmonizing variables across cohort studies to facilitate multicohort studies.</p><p>METHODS: SONAR used semantic learning from variable descriptions and distribution learning from study participant data. Our method learned an embedding vector for each variable and used pairwise cosine similarity to score the similarity between variables. This approach was built off 3 National Institutes of Health cohorts, including the Cardiovascular Health Study, the Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis, and the Women's Health Initiative. We also used gold standard labels to further refine the embeddings in a supervised manner.</p><p>RESULTS: The method was evaluated using manually curated gold standard labels from the 3 National Institutes of Health cohorts. We evaluated both the intracohort and intercohort variable harmonization performance. The supervised SONAR method outperformed existing benchmark methods for almost all intracohort and intercohort comparisons using area under the curve and top-k accuracy metrics. Notably, SONAR was able to significantly improve harmonization of concepts that were difficult for existing semantic methods to harmonize.</p><p>CONCLUSIONS: SONAR achieves accurate variable harmonization within and between cohort studies by harnessing the complementary strengths of semantic learning and variable distribution learning.</p></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-citation hwp-citation--text-additional hwp-bg-light-base js-hwp-citation bibcite-reference" data-component-name="citation" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-citation__text">
<div class="hwp-text-block__default-text">
<div class="bibcite-citation">
<div class="csl-bib-body"><div class="csl-entry"><div class="csl-left-margin">Menezes MCS, Hoffmann AF, Tan ALM, Nalbandyan M, Omenn GS, Mazzotti DR, HernÃ¡ndez-Arango A, Visweswaran S, Venkatesh S, Mandl KD, Bourgeois FT, Lee JWK, Makmur A, Hanauer DA, Semanik MG, Kerivan LT, Hill T, Forero J, Restrepo C, Vigna M, Ceriana P, Abu-El-Rub N, Avillach P, Bellazzi R, Callaci T, GutiÃ©rrez-SacristÃ¡n A, Malovini A, Mathew JP, Morris M, Murthy VL, Buonocore TM, Parimbelli E, Patel LP, Saez C, Samayamuthu MJ, Thompson JA, Tibollo V, Xia Z, Kohane IS, Records C for CC of C 19 by EH. <a href="/publication/potential-generative-pre-trained-transformer-4-gpt-4-analyse-medical-notes-three">The potential of Generative Pre-trained Transformer 4 (GPT-4) to analyse medical notes in three different languages: a retrospective model-evaluation study.</a>.</div><div class="csl-right-inline">The Lancet. Digital health. 2025;7(1):e35-e43. PMID: 39722251</div></div></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-text-block">
<div class="bibcite-citation">
<div class="csl-bib-body"><div class="csl-entry"><div class="csl-left-margin">Menezes MCS, Hoffmann AF, Tan ALM, Nalbandyan M, Omenn GS, Mazzotti DR, HernÃ¡ndez-Arango A, Visweswaran S, Venkatesh S, Mandl KD, Bourgeois FT, Lee JWK, Makmur A, Hanauer DA, Semanik MG, Kerivan LT, Hill T, Forero J, Restrepo C, Vigna M, Ceriana P, Abu-El-Rub N, Avillach P, Bellazzi R, Callaci T, GutiÃ©rrez-SacristÃ¡n A, Malovini A, Mathew JP, Morris M, Murthy VL, Buonocore TM, Parimbelli E, Patel LP, Saez C, Samayamuthu MJ, Thompson JA, Tibollo V, Xia Z, Kohane IS, Records C for CC of C 19 by EH. <a href="/publication/potential-generative-pre-trained-transformer-4-gpt-4-analyse-medical-notes-three">The potential of Generative Pre-trained Transformer 4 (GPT-4) to analyse medical notes in three different languages: a retrospective model-evaluation study.</a>.</div><div class="csl-right-inline">The Lancet. Digital health. 2025;7(1):e35-e43. PMID: 39722251</div></div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<ul class="hwp-citation__ctas">
<li class="expand-button-wrap">
<button aria-controls="hwp-citation-body-content-303159569" aria-expanded="false" class="hwp-text-link hwp-text-link--icon-left hwp-citation__full-body-expand js-hwp-citation__full-body-expand">
<span aria-hidden="true" class="material-icon material-icon--show">add_circle</span>
<span aria-hidden="true" class="material-icon material-icon--hide">do_not_disturb_on</span>
<span class="hwp-text-link__text">Abstract</span>
</button>
</li>
</ul>
<div aria-hidden="true" class="hwp-citation__full-body" id="hwp-citation-body-content-303159569">
<div class="hwp-text-block">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-bibcite-abst-e field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>BACKGROUND: Patient notes contain substantial information but are difficult for computers to analyse due to their unstructured format. Large-language models (LLMs), such as Generative Pre-trained Transformer 4 (GPT-4), have changed our ability to process text, but we do not know how effectively they handle medical notes. We aimed to assess the ability of GPT-4 to answer predefined questions after reading medical notes in three different languages.</p><p>METHODS: For this retrospective model-evaluation study, we included eight university hospitals from four countries (ie, the USA, Colombia, Singapore, and Italy). Each site submitted seven de-identified medical notes related to seven separate patients to the coordinating centre between June 1, 2023, and Feb 28, 2024. Medical notes were written between Feb 1, 2020, and June 1, 2023. One site provided medical notes in Spanish, one site provided notes in Italian, and the remaining six sites provided notes in English. We included admission notes, progress notes, and consultation notes. No discharge summaries were included in this study. We advised participating sites to choose medical notes that, at time of hospital admission, were for patients who were male or female, aged 18-65 years, had a diagnosis of obesity, had a diagnosis of COVID-19, and had submitted an admission note. Adherence to these criteria was optional and participating sites randomly chose which medical notes to submit. When entering information into GPT-4, we prepended each medical note with an instruction prompt and a list of 14 questions that had been chosen a priori. Each medical note was individually given to GPT-4 in its original language and in separate sessions; the questions were always given in English. At each site, two physicians independently validated responses by GPT-4 and responded to all 14 questions. Each pair of physicians evaluated responses from GPT-4 to the seven medical notes from their own site only. Physicians were not masked to responses from GPT-4 before providing their own answers, but were masked to responses from the other physician.</p><p>FINDINGS: We collected 56 medical notes, of which 42 (75%) were in English, seven (13%) were in Italian, and seven (13%) were in Spanish. For each medical note, GPT-4 responded to 14 questions, resulting in 784 responses. In 622 (79%, 95% CI 76-82) of 784 responses, both physicians agreed with GPT-4. In 82 (11%, 8-13) responses, only one physician agreed with GPT-4. In the remaining 80 (10%, 8-13) responses, neither physician agreed with GPT-4. Both physicians agreed with GPT-4 more often for medical notes written in Spanish (86 [88%, 95% CI 79-93] of 98 responses) and Italian (82 [84%, 75-90] of 98 responses) than in English (454 [77%, 74-80] of 588 responses).</p><p>INTERPRETATION: The results of our model-evaluation study suggest that GPT-4 is accurate when analysing medical notes in three different languages. In the future, research should explore how LLMs can be integrated into clinical workflows to maximise their use in health care.</p><p>FUNDING: None.</p></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-citations-group">
<h3 class="h3 hwp-mb-24">2024</h3>
<div class="hwp-citations-group__inner">
<div class="hwp-citation hwp-citation--text-additional hwp-bg-light-base js-hwp-citation bibcite-reference" data-component-name="citation" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-citation__text">
<div class="hwp-text-block__default-text">
<div class="bibcite-citation">
<div class="csl-bib-body"><div class="csl-entry"><div class="csl-left-margin">GutiÃ©rrez-SacristÃ¡n A, Makwana S, Dionne A, Mahanta S, Dyer KJ, Serrano F, Watrin C, Pages P, Mousavi S, Degala A, Lyons J, Pillion D, Zachariasse JM, Shekerdemian LS, Truong DT, Newburger JW, Avillach P. <a href="/publication/development-and-validation-open-source-pipeline-automatic-population-case-report-forms">Development and validation of an open-source pipeline for automatic population of case report forms from electronic health records: a pediatric multi-center prospective study.</a>.</div><div class="csl-right-inline">EBioMedicine. 2024;108:105337. PMID: 39288532</div></div></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-text-block">
<div class="bibcite-citation">
<div class="csl-bib-body"><div class="csl-entry"><div class="csl-left-margin">GutiÃ©rrez-SacristÃ¡n A, Makwana S, Dionne A, Mahanta S, Dyer KJ, Serrano F, Watrin C, Pages P, Mousavi S, Degala A, Lyons J, Pillion D, Zachariasse JM, Shekerdemian LS, Truong DT, Newburger JW, Avillach P. <a href="/publication/development-and-validation-open-source-pipeline-automatic-population-case-report-forms">Development and validation of an open-source pipeline for automatic population of case report forms from electronic health records: a pediatric multi-center prospective study.</a>.</div><div class="csl-right-inline">EBioMedicine. 2024;108:105337. PMID: 39288532</div></div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<ul class="hwp-citation__ctas">
<li class="expand-button-wrap">
<button aria-controls="hwp-citation-body-content-613921253" aria-expanded="false" class="hwp-text-link hwp-text-link--icon-left hwp-citation__full-body-expand js-hwp-citation__full-body-expand">
<span aria-hidden="true" class="material-icon material-icon--show">add_circle</span>
<span aria-hidden="true" class="material-icon material-icon--hide">do_not_disturb_on</span>
<span class="hwp-text-link__text">Abstract</span>
</button>
</li>
</ul>
<div aria-hidden="true" class="hwp-citation__full-body" id="hwp-citation-body-content-613921253">
<div class="hwp-text-block">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-bibcite-abst-e field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>BACKGROUND: Clinical trials and registry studies are essential for advancing research and developing novel treatments. However, these studies rely on manual entry of thousands of variables for each patient. Repurposing real-world data can significantly simplify the data collection, reduce transcription errors, and make the data entry process more efficient, consistent, and cost-effective.</p><p>METHODS: We developed an open-source computational pipeline to collect laboratory and medication information from the electronic health record (EHR) data and populate case report forms. The pipeline was developed and validated with data from two independent pediatric hospitals in the US as part of the Long-terM OUtcomes after Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome In Children (MUSIC) study. Our pipeline allowed the completion of two of the most time-consuming forms. We compared automatically extracted results with manually entered values in one hospital and applied the pipeline to a second hospital, where the output served as the primary data source for case report forms.</p><p>FINDINGS: We extracted and populated 51,845 laboratory and 4913 medication values for 159 patients in two hospitals participating in a prospective pediatric study. We evaluated pipeline performance against data for 104 patients manually entered by clinicians in one of the hospitals. The highest concordance was found during patient hospitalization, with 91.59% of the automatically extracted laboratory and medication values corresponding with the manually entered values. In addition to the successfully populated values, we identified an additional 13,396 laboratory and 567 medication values of interest for the study.</p><p>INTERPRETATION: The automatic data entry of laboratory and medication values during admission is feasible and has a high concordance with the manually entered data. By implementing this proof of concept, we demonstrate the quality of automatic data extraction and highlight the potential of secondary use of EHR data to advance medical science by improving data entry efficiency and expediting clinical research.</p><p>FUNDING: NIH Grant 1OT3HL147154-01, U24HL135691, UG1HL135685.</p></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-citation hwp-citation--text-additional hwp-bg-light-base js-hwp-citation bibcite-reference" data-component-name="citation" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-citation__text">
<div class="hwp-text-block__default-text">
<div class="bibcite-citation">
<div class="csl-bib-body"><div class="csl-entry"><div class="csl-left-margin">Yin R, Wack M, Hassen-Khodja C, McDuffie MT, Bliss G, Horn EJ, Kothari C, McLarney B, Davis R, Hanson K, OâBoyle M, Betancur C, Avillach P. <a href="/publication/phenome-wide-profiling-identifies-genotype-phenotype-associations-phelan-mcdermid">Phenome-wide profiling identifies genotype-phenotype associations in Phelan-McDermid syndrome using family-sourced data from an international registry.</a>.</div><div class="csl-right-inline">Molecular autism. 2024;15(1):40. PMID: 39350236</div></div></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-text-block">
<div class="bibcite-citation">
<div class="csl-bib-body"><div class="csl-entry"><div class="csl-left-margin">Yin R, Wack M, Hassen-Khodja C, McDuffie MT, Bliss G, Horn EJ, Kothari C, McLarney B, Davis R, Hanson K, OâBoyle M, Betancur C, Avillach P. <a href="/publication/phenome-wide-profiling-identifies-genotype-phenotype-associations-phelan-mcdermid">Phenome-wide profiling identifies genotype-phenotype associations in Phelan-McDermid syndrome using family-sourced data from an international registry.</a>.</div><div class="csl-right-inline">Molecular autism. 2024;15(1):40. PMID: 39350236</div></div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<ul class="hwp-citation__ctas">
<li class="expand-button-wrap">
<button aria-controls="hwp-citation-body-content-1645799944" aria-expanded="false" class="hwp-text-link hwp-text-link--icon-left hwp-citation__full-body-expand js-hwp-citation__full-body-expand">
<span aria-hidden="true" class="material-icon material-icon--show">add_circle</span>
<span aria-hidden="true" class="material-icon material-icon--hide">do_not_disturb_on</span>
<span class="hwp-text-link__text">Abstract</span>
</button>
</li>
</ul>
<div aria-hidden="true" class="hwp-citation__full-body" id="hwp-citation-body-content-1645799944">
<div class="hwp-text-block">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-bibcite-abst-e field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>BACKGROUND: Phelan-McDermid syndrome (PMS) is a rare neurodevelopmental disorder caused by 22q13 deletions that include the SHANK3 gene or pathogenic sequenceÂ variants in SHANK3. It is characterized by global developmental delay, intellectual disability, speech impairment, autism spectrum disorder, and hypotonia; other variable features include epilepsy, brain and renal malformations, and mild dysmorphic features. Here, we conducted genotype-phenotype correlation analyses using the PMS International Registry, a family-driven registry that compiles clinical data in the form of family-reported outcomes and family-sourced genetic test results.</p><p>METHODS: Data from the registry were harmonized and integrated into the i2b2/tranSMART clinical and genomics data warehouse. We gathered information from 401 individuals with 22q13 deletions including SHANK3 (nâ=â350, ranging in size from 10Â kb to 9.1Â Mb) or pathogenic or likely pathogenic SHANK3 sequence variants (nâ=â51), and used regression models with deletion size as a potential predictor of clinical outcomes for 328 phenotypes.</p><p>RESULTS: Our results showed that increased deletion size was significantly associated with delay in gross and fine motor acquisitions, a spectrum of conditions related to poor muscle tone, renal malformations, mild dysmorphic features (e.g., large fleshy hands, sacral dimple, dysplastic toenails, supernumerary teeth), lymphedema, congenital heart defects, and more frequent neuroimaging abnormalities and infections. These findings indicate that genes upstream of SHANK3 also contribute to some of the manifestations of PMS in individuals with larger deletions. We also showed that self-help skills, verbal ability and a range of psychiatric diagnoses (e.g., autism, ADHD, anxiety disorder) were more common among individuals with smaller deletions and SHANK3 variants.</p><p>LIMITATIONS: Some participants were tested with targeted 22q microarrays rather than genome-wide arrays, and karyotypes were unavailable in many cases, thus precluding the analysis of the effect of other copy number variants or chromosomal rearrangements on the phenotype.</p><p>CONCLUSIONS: This is the largest reported case series of individuals with PMS. Overall, we demonstrate the feasibility of using data from a family-sourced registry to conduct genotype-phenotype analyses in rare genetic disorders. We replicate and strengthen previous findings, and reveal novel associations between larger 22q13 deletions and congenital heart defects, neuroimaging abnormalities and recurrent infections.</p></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-citation hwp-citation--text-additional hwp-bg-light-base js-hwp-citation bibcite-reference" data-component-name="citation" lang="en">

<div class="hwp-text-block__default-text">
<div class="bibcite-citation">
<div class="csl-bib-body"><div class="csl-entry"><div class="csl-left-margin">HernÃ¡ndez-Agosto J, Santiago-QuiÃ±ones DI, GarcÃ­a-Carmona LM, GutiÃ©rrez-SacristÃ¡n A. <a href="/publication/substance-use-disorders-and-disparities-hispanic-and-non-hispanic-older-adults">Substance use disorders and disparities in hispanic and non-hispanic older adults.</a>.</div><div class="csl-right-inline">Drug and alcohol dependence. 2024;261:111357. PMID: 38896947</div></div></div>
</div>

<div class="hwp-text-block">
<div class="bibcite-citation">
<div class="csl-bib-body"><div class="csl-entry"><div class="csl-left-margin">HernÃ¡ndez-Agosto J, Santiago-QuiÃ±ones DI, GarcÃ­a-Carmona LM, GutiÃ©rrez-SacristÃ¡n A. <a href="/publication/substance-use-disorders-and-disparities-hispanic-and-non-hispanic-older-adults">Substance use disorders and disparities in hispanic and non-hispanic older adults.</a>.</div><div class="csl-right-inline">Drug and alcohol dependence. 2024;261:111357. PMID: 38896947</div></div></div>

<ul class="hwp-citation__ctas">
<li class="expand-button-wrap">
<button aria-controls="hwp-citation-body-content-2110352893" aria-expanded="false" class="hwp-text-link hwp-text-link--icon-left hwp-citation__full-body-expand js-hwp-citation__full-body-expand">
<span aria-hidden="true" class="material-icon material-icon--show">add_circle</span>
<span aria-hidden="true" class="material-icon material-icon--hide">do_not_disturb_on</span>
<span class="hwp-text-link__text">Abstract</span>
</button>
</li>
</ul>
<div aria-hidden="true" class="hwp-citation__full-body" id="hwp-citation-body-content-2110352893">
<div class="hwp-text-block">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-bibcite-abst-e field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>BACKGROUND: The global longevity revolution increased the older adult population, posing unique health and economic challenges with implications for healthcare, especially substance use disorders (SUD).</p><p>METHODS: This was a retrospective cohort study of United States older adults, Hispanic and non-Hispanic, who got at least one mental and/or behavioral disorder diagnosis between 2017 and 2021 at age 65 or older. SUD prevalence, prescription frequency changes over time, and comorbidities associated with each medication were compared.</p><p>RESULTS: Electronic health records for 356,133 older adults (110,236 Hispanics and 245,897 non-Hispanics) were analyzed. Notably, 79â% of Hispanics fell below the 100â% federal poverty level, compared to 60â% of non-Hispanics (P&lt;.001). Non-Hispanics also had significantly more average encounters (P=.003) and diagnoses (P&lt;.001). Regression analysis on alcohol-related disorders indicated that the odd ratios of being male (OR=2.93, P&lt;.000), and having low income (OR=1.62, P&lt;.000), increase the odds for this SUD, while being Hispanic and primarily speaking Spanish decreases the odds for all SUDs considered in this study.</p><p>CONCLUSIONS: This cohort study revealed significant disparities related to social determinants of health between Hispanic and non-Hispanic older adults and emphasizes the need for continuous surveillance of older adults as with SUDs. Differences in comorbidity patterns imply distinct risk factors within each population, influenced by demographic-specific elements. Recognizing these variations is essential for tailoring culturally sensitive prevention, intervention, and treatment strategies to each population's unique needs.</p></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-citation hwp-citation--text-additional hwp-bg-light-base js-hwp-citation bibcite-reference" data-component-name="citation" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-citation__text">
<div class="hwp-text-block__default-text">
<div class="bibcite-citation">
<div class="csl-bib-body"><div class="csl-entry"><div class="csl-left-margin">Yin R, Gutierrez A, Network UD, Kobren SN, Avillach P. <a href="/publication/varppud-variant-post-prioritization-developed-undiagnosed-genetic-disorders">VarPPUD: Variant post prioritization developed for undiagnosed genetic disorders.</a>.</div><div class="csl-right-inline">medRxiv : the preprint server for health sciences. 2024; PMID: 38699371</div></div></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-text-block">
<div class="bibcite-citation">
<div class="csl-bib-body"><div class="csl-entry"><div class="csl-left-margin">Yin R, Gutierrez A, Network UD, Kobren SN, Avillach P. <a href="/publication/varppud-variant-post-prioritization-developed-undiagnosed-genetic-disorders">VarPPUD: Variant post prioritization developed for undiagnosed genetic disorders.</a>.</div><div class="csl-right-inline">medRxiv : the preprint server for health sciences. 2024; PMID: 38699371</div></div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<ul class="hwp-citation__ctas">
<li class="expand-button-wrap">
<button aria-controls="hwp-citation-body-content-551639828" aria-expanded="false" class="hwp-text-link hwp-text-link--icon-left hwp-citation__full-body-expand js-hwp-citation__full-body-expand">
<span aria-hidden="true" class="material-icon material-icon--show">add_circle</span>
<span aria-hidden="true" class="material-icon material-icon--hide">do_not_disturb_on</span>
<span class="hwp-text-link__text">Abstract</span>
</button>
</li>
</ul>
<div aria-hidden="true" class="hwp-citation__full-body" id="hwp-citation-body-content-551639828">
<div class="hwp-text-block">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-bibcite-abst-e field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>Rare and ultra-rare genetic conditions are estimated to impact nearly 1 in 17 people worldwide, yet accurately pinpointing the diagnostic variants underlying each of these conditions remains a formidable challenge. Because comprehensive,  functional assessment of all possible genetic variants is infeasible, clinicians instead consider  variant pathogenicity predictions to distinguish plausibly disease-causing from benign variants across the genome. However, in the most difficult undiagnosed cases, such as those accepted to the Undiagnosed Diseases Network (UDN), existing pathogenicity predictions cannot reliably discern true etiological variant(s) from other deleterious candidate variants that were prioritized through N-of-1 efforts. Pinpointing the disease-causing variant from a pool of plausible candidates remains a largely manual effort requiring extensive clinical workups, functional and experimental assays, and eventual identification of genotype- and phenotype-matched individuals. Here, we introduce VarPPUD, a tool trained on prioritized variants from UDN cases, that leverages gene-, amino acid-, and nucleotide-level features to discern pathogenic variants from other deleterious variants that are unlikely to be confirmed as disease relevant. VarPPUD achieves a cross-validated accuracy of 79.3% and precision of 77.5% on a held-out subset of uniquely challenging UDN cases, respectively representing an average 18.6% and 23.4% improvement over nine traditional pathogenicity prediction approaches on this task. We validate VarPPUD's ability to discriminate likely from unlikely pathogenic variants on synthetic, GAN-generated candidate variants as well. Finally, we show how VarPPUD can be probed to evaluate each input feature's importance and contribution toward prediction-an essential step toward understanding the distinct characteristics of newly-uncovered disease-causing variants.</p></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-citation hwp-citation--text-additional hwp-bg-light-base js-hwp-citation bibcite-reference" data-component-name="citation" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-citation__text">
<div class="hwp-text-block__default-text">
<div class="bibcite-citation">
<div class="csl-bib-body"><div class="csl-entry"><div class="csl-left-margin">Hutch MR, Son J, Le TT, Hong C, Wang X, Abad ZSH, Morris M, GutiÃ©rrez-SacristÃ¡n A, Klann JG, Spiridou A, Batugo A, Bellazzi R, Benoit V, Bonzel CL, Bryant WA, Chiudinelli L, Cho K, Das P, GonzÃ¡lez TG, Hanauer DA, Henderson DW, Ho YL, Loh NHW, Makoudjou A, Makwana S, Malovini A, Moal B, Mowery DL, Neuraz A, Samayamuthu MJ, Vidorreta FJS, Schriver ER, Schubert P, Talbert J, Tan ALM, Tan BWL, Tan BWQ, Tibollo V, Tippman P, Verdy G, Yuan W, Avillach P, Gehlenborg N, Omenn GS, EHR C for CC of C 19 by, Visweswaran S, Cai T, Luo Y, Xia Z. <a href="/publication/neurological-diagnoses-hospitalized-covid-19-patients-associated-adverse-outcomes">Neurological diagnoses in hospitalized COVID-19 patients associated with adverse outcomes: A multinational cohort study.</a>.</div><div class="csl-right-inline">PLOS digital health. 2024;3(4):e0000484. PMID: 38620037</div></div></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-text-block">
<div class="bibcite-citation">
<div class="csl-bib-body"><div class="csl-entry"><div class="csl-left-margin">Hutch MR, Son J, Le TT, Hong C, Wang X, Abad ZSH, Morris M, GutiÃ©rrez-SacristÃ¡n A, Klann JG, Spiridou A, Batugo A, Bellazzi R, Benoit V, Bonzel CL, Bryant WA, Chiudinelli L, Cho K, Das P, GonzÃ¡lez TG, Hanauer DA, Henderson DW, Ho YL, Loh NHW, Makoudjou A, Makwana S, Malovini A, Moal B, Mowery DL, Neuraz A, Samayamuthu MJ, Vidorreta FJS, Schriver ER, Schubert P, Talbert J, Tan ALM, Tan BWL, Tan BWQ, Tibollo V, Tippman P, Verdy G, Yuan W, Avillach P, Gehlenborg N, Omenn GS, EHR C for CC of C 19 by, Visweswaran S, Cai T, Luo Y, Xia Z. <a href="/publication/neurological-diagnoses-hospitalized-covid-19-patients-associated-adverse-outcomes">Neurological diagnoses in hospitalized COVID-19 patients associated with adverse outcomes: A multinational cohort study.</a>.</div><div class="csl-right-inline">PLOS digital health. 2024;3(4):e0000484. PMID: 38620037</div></div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<ul class="hwp-citation__ctas">
<li class="expand-button-wrap">
<button aria-controls="hwp-citation-body-content-2100453899" aria-expanded="false" class="hwp-text-link hwp-text-link--icon-left hwp-citation__full-body-expand js-hwp-citation__full-body-expand">
<span aria-hidden="true" class="material-icon material-icon--show">add_circle</span>
<span aria-hidden="true" class="material-icon material-icon--hide">do_not_disturb_on</span>
<span class="hwp-text-link__text">Abstract</span>
</button>
</li>
</ul>
<div aria-hidden="true" class="hwp-citation__full-body" id="hwp-citation-body-content-2100453899">
<div class="hwp-text-block">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-bibcite-abst-e field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>Few studies examining the patient outcomes of concurrent neurological manifestations during acute COVID-19 leveraged multinational cohorts of adults and children or distinguished between central and peripheral nervous system (CNS vs. PNS) involvement. Using a federated multinational network in which local clinicians and informatics experts curated the electronic health records data, we evaluated the risk of prolonged hospitalization and mortality in hospitalized COVID-19 patients from 21 healthcare systems across 7 countries. For adults, we used a federated learning approach whereby we ran Cox proportional hazard models locally at each healthcare system and performed a meta-analysis on the aggregated results to estimate the overall risk of adverse outcomes across our geographically diverse populations. For children, we reported descriptive statistics separately due to their low frequency of neurological involvement and poor outcomes. Among the 106,229 hospitalized COVID-19 patients (104,031 patients â¥18 years; 2,198 patients &lt;18 years, January 2020-October 2021), 15,101 (14%) had at least one CNS diagnosis, while 2,788 (3%) had at least one PNS diagnosis. After controlling for demographics and pre-existing conditions, adults with CNS involvement had longer hospital stay (11 versus 6 days) and greater risk of (Hazard Ratio = 1.78) and faster time to death (12 versus 24 days) than patients with no neurological condition (NNC) during acute COVID-19 hospitalization. Adults with PNS involvement also had longer hospital stay but lower risk of mortality than the NNC group. Although children had a low frequency of neurological involvement during COVID-19 hospitalization, a substantially higher proportion of children with CNS involvement died compared to those with NNC (6% vs 1%). Overall, patients with concurrent CNS manifestation during acute COVID-19 hospitalization faced greater risks for adverse clinical outcomes than patients without any neurological diagnosis. Our global informatics framework using a federated approach (versus a centralized data collection approach) has utility for clinical discovery beyond COVID-19.</p></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-citation hwp-citation--text-additional hwp-bg-light-base js-hwp-citation bibcite-reference" data-component-name="citation" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-citation__text">
<div class="hwp-text-block__default-text">
<div class="bibcite-citation">
<div class="csl-bib-body"><div class="csl-entry"><div class="csl-left-margin">Huang M, GutiÃ©rrez-SacristÃ¡n A, Janiak E, Young K, Starosta A, Blanton K, Azhir A, Goldfarb CN, Kuperwasser F, Schaefer KM, Stoddard RE, Vatsa R, Merz-Herrala AA, Bartz D. <a href="/publication/contraceptive-content-shared-social-media-analysis-twitter">Contraceptive content shared on social media: an analysis of Twitter.</a>.</div><div class="csl-right-inline">Contraception and reproductive medicine. 2024;9(1):5. PMID: 38321582</div></div></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-text-block">
<div class="bibcite-citation">
<div class="csl-bib-body"><div class="csl-entry"><div class="csl-left-margin">Huang M, GutiÃ©rrez-SacristÃ¡n A, Janiak E, Young K, Starosta A, Blanton K, Azhir A, Goldfarb CN, Kuperwasser F, Schaefer KM, Stoddard RE, Vatsa R, Merz-Herrala AA, Bartz D. <a href="/publication/contraceptive-content-shared-social-media-analysis-twitter">Contraceptive content shared on social media: an analysis of Twitter.</a>.</div><div class="csl-right-inline">Contraception and reproductive medicine. 2024;9(1):5. PMID: 38321582</div></div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<ul class="hwp-citation__ctas">
<li class="expand-button-wrap">
<button aria-controls="hwp-citation-body-content-1649283050" aria-expanded="false" class="hwp-text-link hwp-text-link--icon-left hwp-citation__full-body-expand js-hwp-citation__full-body-expand">
<span aria-hidden="true" class="material-icon material-icon--show">add_circle</span>
<span aria-hidden="true" class="material-icon material-icon--hide">do_not_disturb_on</span>
<span class="hwp-text-link__text">Abstract</span>
</button>
</li>
</ul>
<div aria-hidden="true" class="hwp-citation__full-body" id="hwp-citation-body-content-1649283050">
<div class="hwp-text-block">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-bibcite-abst-e field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>BACKGROUND: Information on social media may affect peoples' contraceptive decision making. We performed an exploratory analysis of contraceptive content on Twitter (recently renamed X), a popular social media platform.</p><p>METHODS: We selected a random subset of 1% of publicly available, English-language tweets related to reversible, prescription contraceptive methods posted between January 2014 and December 2019. We oversampled tweets for the contraceptive patch to ensure at least 200 tweets per method. To create the codebook, we identified common themes specific to tweet content topics, tweet sources, and tweets soliciting information or providing advice. All posts were coded by two team members, and differences were adjudicated by a third reviewer. Descriptive analyses were reported with accompanying qualitative findings.</p><p>RESULTS: During the study period, 457,369 tweets about reversible contraceptive methods were published, with a random sample of 4,434 tweets used for final analysis. Tweets most frequently discussed contraceptive method decision-making (26.7%) and side effects (20.5%), particularly for long-acting reversible contraceptive methods and the depot medroxyprogesterone acetate shot. Tweets about logistics of use or adherence were common for short-acting reversible contraceptives. Tweets were frequently posted by contraceptive consumers (50.6%). A small proportion of tweets explicitly requested information (6.2%) or provided advice (4.2%).</p><p>CONCLUSIONS: Clinicians should be aware that individuals are exposed to information through Twitter that may affect contraceptive perceptions and decision making, particularly regarding long-acting reversible contraceptives. Social media is a valuable source for studying contraceptive beliefs missing in traditional health research and may be used by professionals to disseminate accurate contraceptive information.</p></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-citation hwp-citation--text-additional hwp-bg-light-base js-hwp-citation bibcite-reference" data-component-name="citation" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-citation__text">
<div class="hwp-text-block__default-text">
<div class="bibcite-citation">
<div class="csl-bib-body"><div class="csl-entry"><div class="csl-left-margin">Gargano MA, Matentzoglu N, Coleman B, Addo-Lartey EB, Anagnostopoulos A V, Anderton J, Avillach P, Bagley AM, BakÅ¡tein E, Balhoff JP, Baynam G, Bello SM, Berk M, Bertram H, Bishop S, Blau H, Bodenstein DF, Botas P, Boztug K, Äady J, Callahan TJ, Cameron R, Carbon SJ, Castellanos F, Caufield H, Chan LE, Chute CG, Cruz-Rojo J, Dahan-Oliel N, Davids JR, de Dieuleveult M, de Souza V, de Vries BBA, de Vries E, DePaulo R, Derfalvi B, Dhombres F, Diaz-Byrd C, Dingemans AJM, Donadille B, Duyzend M, Elfeky R, Essaid S, Fabrizzi C, Fico G, Firth H V, Freudenberg-Hua Y, Fullerton JM, Gabriel DL, Gilmour K, Giordano J, Goes FS, Moses RG, Green I, Griese M, Groza T, Gu W, Guthrie J, Gyori B, Hamosh A, Hanauer M, HanuÅ¡ovÃ¡ K, He YO, Hegde H, Helbig I, HolasovÃ¡ K, Hoyt CT, Huang S, Hurwitz E, Jacobsen JOB, Jiang X, Joseph L, Keramatian K, King B, Knoflach K, Koolen DA, Kraus ML, Kroll C, Kusters M, Ladewig MS, Lagorce D, Lai MC, Lapunzina P, Laraway B, Lewis-Smith D, Li X, Lucano C, Majd M, Marazita ML, Martinez-Glez V, McHenry TH, McInnis MG, McMurry JA, MihulovÃ¡ M, Millett CE, Mitchell PB, MoslerovÃ¡
