<!-- Source: avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/publication/neurological-diagnoses-hospitalized-covid-19-patients-associated-adverse-outcomes -->
<h1>Neurological diagnoses in hospitalized COVID-19 patients associated with adverse outcomes: A multinational cohort study. | Avillach Lab</h1>
<div class='source-url'><a href='https://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/publication/neurological-diagnoses-hospitalized-covid-19-patients-associated-adverse-outcomes'>avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/publication/neurological-diagnoses-hospitalized-covid-19-patients-associated-adverse-outcomes</a></div>
<main aria-labelledby="page-title" id="main-content" lang="en" role="main" tabindex="-1">
<div class="layout-content">
<div>
<div class="hidden" data-drupal-messages-fallback=""></div>
<div class="biblio-details">
<div class="hwp-page-title bibcite-reference" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
<h1 class="text-large">
      Neurological diagnoses in hospitalized COVID-19 patients associated with adverse outcomes: A multinational cohort study.
    </h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="md:hwp-pt-64">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px max-lg:hwp-px-0">
<div class="publication-info" data-component-name="publication-info">
<div class="publication-info__image">
</div>
<div class="publication-info__text">
<h4 class="h4 hwp-mb-8">Publication information:</h4>
<div class="publication-info__body">
<div class="bibcite-citation">
<div class="csl-bib-body"><div class="csl-entry"><div class="csl-left-margin">Hutch MR, Son J, Le TT, Hong C, Wang X, Abad ZSH, Morris M, GutiÃ©rrez-SacristÃ¡n A, Klann JG, Spiridou A, Batugo A, Bellazzi R, Benoit V, Bonzel CL, Bryant WA, Chiudinelli L, Cho K, Das P, GonzÃ¡lez TG, Hanauer DA, Henderson DW, Ho YL, Loh NHW, Makoudjou A, Makwana S, Malovini A, Moal B, Mowery DL, Neuraz A, Samayamuthu MJ, Vidorreta FJS, Schriver ER, Schubert P, Talbert J, Tan ALM, Tan BWL, Tan BWQ, Tibollo V, Tippman P, Verdy G, Yuan W, Avillach P, Gehlenborg N, Omenn GS, EHR C for CC of C 19 by, Visweswaran S, Cai T, Luo Y, Xia Z. Neurological diagnoses in hospitalized COVID-19 patients associated with adverse outcomes: A multinational cohort study.</div><div class="csl-right-inline">PLOS digital health. 2024;3(4):e0000484. PMID: 38620037</div></div></div>
</div>
</div>
<ul class="publication-info__actions">
<li>
<div class="button-dropdown" data-component-name="button-dropdown">
<button class="hwp-text-link hwp-text-link--icon-left" id="publication_citation_download">
<span aria-hidden="true" class="material-icon">download_for_offline</span>
<span class="hwp-text-link__text">Download citation</span>
</button>
<ul aria-labelledby="publication_citation_download" class="button-dropdown__items" role="menu">
<li role="menuitem">
<a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773921&amp;format=bibtex">BibTeX</a>
</li>
<li role="menuitem">
<a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773921&amp;format=endnote8">EndNote X3 XML</a>
</li>
<li role="menuitem">
<a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773921&amp;format=endnote7">EndNote 7 XML</a>
</li>
<li role="menuitem">
<a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773921&amp;format=tagged">Endnote tagged</a>
</li>
<li role="menuitem">
<a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773921&amp;format=marc">Marc</a>
</li>
<li role="menuitem">
<a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773921&amp;format=pubmed_id">PubMedId</a>
</li>
<li role="menuitem">
<a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773921&amp;format=ris">RIS</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-pt-32 hwp-pb-64 md:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-citations-group">
<h3 class="h3 hwp-mb-24">Abstract</h3>
<div class="hwp-citations-group__inner">
<div class="hwp-citation hwp-citation--text-trim hwp-bg-light-base js-hwp-citation" data-component-name="citation">
<div class="hwp-citation__text">
<div class="hwp-text-block__default-text">
<p>Few studies examining the patient outcomes of concurrent neurological manifestations during acute COVID-19 leveraged multinational cohorts of adults and children or distinguished between central and peripheral nervous system (CNS vs. PNS) involvement. Using a federated multinational network in which local clinicians and informatics experts curated the electronic health records data, we evaluated the risk of prolonged hospitalization and mortality in hospitalized COVID-19 patients from 21 healthcare systems across 7 countries. For adults, we used a federated learning approach whereby we ran Cox proportional hazard models locally at each healthcare system and performed a meta-analysis on the aggregated results to estimate the overall risk of adverse outcomes across our geographically diverse populations. For children, we reported descriptive statistics separately due to their low frequency of neurological involvement and poor outcomes. Among the 106,229 hospitalized COVID-19 patients (104,031 patients â¥18 years; 2,198 patients &lt;18 years, January 2020-October 2021), 15,101 (14%) had at least one CNS diagnosis, while 2,788 (3%) had at least one PNS diagnosis. After controlling for demographics and pre-existing conditions, adults with CNS involvement had longer hospital stay (11 versus 6 days) and greater risk of (Hazard Ratio = 1.78) and faster time to death (12 versus 24 days) than patients with no neurological condition (NNC) during acute COVID-19 hospitalization. Adults with PNS involvement also had longer hospital stay but lower risk of mortality than the NNC group. Although children had a low frequency of neurological involvement during COVID-19 hospitalization, a substantially higher proportion of children with CNS involvement died compared to those with NNC (6% vs 1%). Overall, patients with concurrent CNS manifestation during acute COVID-19 hospitalization faced greater risks for adverse clinical outcomes than patients without any neurological diagnosis. Our global informatics framework using a federated approach (versus a centralized data collection approach) has utility for clinical discovery beyond COVID-19.</p>
</div>
<div class="hwp-text-block">
<p>Few studies examining the patient outcomes of concurrent neurological manifestations during acute COVID-19 leveraged multinational cohorts of adults and children or distinguished between central and peripheral nervous system (CNS vs. PNS) involvement. Using a federated multinational network in which local clinicians and informatics experts curated the electronic health records data, we evaluated the risk of prolonged hospitalization and mortality in hospitalized COVID-19 patients from 21 healthcare systems across 7 countries. For adults, we used a federated learning approach whereby we ran Cox proportional hazard models locally at each healthcare system and performed a meta-analysis on the aggregated results to estimate the overall risk of adverse outcomes across our geographically diverse populations. For children, we reported descriptive statistics separately due to their low frequency of neurological involvement and poor outcomes. Among the 106,229 hospitalized COVID-19 patients (104,031 patients â¥18 years; 2,198 patients &lt;18 years, January 2020-October 2021), 15,101 (14%) had at least one CNS diagnosis, while 2,788 (3%) had at least one PNS diagnosis. After controlling for demographics and pre-existing conditions, adults with CNS involvement had longer hospital stay (11 versus 6 days) and greater risk of (Hazard Ratio = 1.78) and faster time to death (12 versus 24 days) than patients with no neurological condition (NNC) during acute COVID-19 hospitalization. Adults with PNS involvement also had longer hospital stay but lower risk of mortality than the NNC group. Although children had a low frequency of neurological involvement during COVID-19 hospitalization, a substantially higher proportion of children with CNS involvement died compared to those with NNC (6% vs 1%). Overall, patients with concurrent CNS manifestation during acute COVID-19 hospitalization faced greater risks for adverse clinical outcomes than patients without any neurological diagnosis. Our global informatics framework using a federated approach (versus a centralized data collection approach) has utility for clinical discovery beyond COVID-19.</p>
</div>
</div>

<span aria-hidden="true" class="material-icon material-icon--show">add_circle</span>

<div class="a2a_kit" data-a2a-title="" data-a2a-url="">
<span class="hwp-mb-16 hwp-block">Share on:</span>
<ul aria-label="Share on:" class="md:hwp-inline-flex md:hwp-flex-wrap">
<li class="md:hwp-mr-40 last:md:hwp-mr-0 max-md:hwp-mb-16">
<a class="a2a_button_facebook hwp-icon-link hwp-icon-link--dark-primary" href="#">
<span class="hwp-icon-link__icon">
<svg aria-hidden="true" class="hwp-icon hwp-h-24 hwp-w-24">

<!-- Source: avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/publication/robust-automated-harmonization-heterogeneous-data-through-ensemble-machine-learning -->
<h1>Robust Automated Harmonization of Heterogeneous Data Through Ensemble Machine Learning: Algorithm Development and Validation Study. | Avillach Lab</h1>
<div class='source-url'><a href='https://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/publication/robust-automated-harmonization-heterogeneous-data-through-ensemble-machine-learning'>avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/publication/robust-automated-harmonization-heterogeneous-data-through-ensemble-machine-learning</a></div>
<main aria-labelledby="page-title" id="main-content" lang="en" role="main" tabindex="-1">
<div class="layout-content">
<div>
<div class="hidden" data-drupal-messages-fallback=""></div>
<div class="biblio-details">
<div class="hwp-page-title bibcite-reference" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
<h1 class="text-large">
      Robust Automated Harmonization of Heterogeneous Data Through Ensemble Machine Learning: Algorithm Development and Validation Study.
    </h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="md:hwp-pt-64">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px max-lg:hwp-px-0">
<div class="publication-info" data-component-name="publication-info">
<div class="publication-info__image">
</div>
<div class="publication-info__text">
<h4 class="h4 hwp-mb-8">Publication information:</h4>
<div class="publication-info__body">
<div class="bibcite-citation">
<div class="csl-bib-body"><div class="csl-entry"><div class="csl-left-margin">Yang D, Zhou D, Cai S, Gan Z, Pencina M, Avillach P, Cai T, Hong C. Robust Automated Harmonization of Heterogeneous Data Through Ensemble Machine Learning: Algorithm Development and Validation Study.</div><div class="csl-right-inline">JMIR medical informatics. 2025;13:e54133. PMID: 39844378</div></div></div>
</div>
</div>
<ul class="publication-info__actions">
<li>
<div class="button-dropdown" data-component-name="button-dropdown">
<button class="hwp-text-link hwp-text-link--icon-left" id="publication_citation_download">
<span aria-hidden="true" class="material-icon">download_for_offline</span>
<span class="hwp-text-link__text">Download citation</span>
</button>
<ul aria-labelledby="publication_citation_download" class="button-dropdown__items" role="menu">
<li role="menuitem">
<a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773891&amp;format=bibtex">BibTeX</a>
</li>
<li role="menuitem">
<a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773891&amp;format=endnote8">EndNote X3 XML</a>
</li>
<li role="menuitem">
<a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773891&amp;format=endnote7">EndNote 7 XML</a>
</li>
<li role="menuitem">
<a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773891&amp;format=tagged">Endnote tagged</a>
</li>
<li role="menuitem">
<a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773891&amp;format=marc">Marc</a>
</li>
<li role="menuitem">
<a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773891&amp;format=pubmed_id">PubMedId</a>
</li>
<li role="menuitem">
<a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773891&amp;format=ris">RIS</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-pt-32 hwp-pb-64 md:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-citations-group">
<h3 class="h3 hwp-mb-24">Abstract</h3>
<div class="hwp-citations-group__inner">
<div class="hwp-citation hwp-citation--text-trim hwp-bg-light-base js-hwp-citation" data-component-name="citation">
<div class="hwp-citation__text">
<div class="hwp-text-block__default-text">
<p><b>BACKGROUND: </b>Cohort studies contain rich clinical data across large and diverse patient populations and are a common source of observational data for clinical research. Because large scale cohort studies are both time and resource intensive, one alternative is to harmonize data from existing cohorts through multicohort studies. However, given differences in variable encoding, accurate variable harmonization is difficult.</p><p><b>OBJECTIVE: </b>We propose SONAR (Semantic and Distribution-Based Harmonization) as a method for harmonizing variables across cohort studies to facilitate multicohort studies.</p><p><b>METHODS: </b>SONAR used semantic learning from variable descriptions and distribution learning from study participant data. Our method learned an embedding vector for each variable and used pairwise cosine similarity to score the similarity between variables. This approach was built off 3 National Institutes of Health cohorts, including the Cardiovascular Health Study, the Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis, and the Women's Health Initiative. We also used gold standard labels to further refine the embeddings in a supervised manner.</p><p><b>RESULTS: </b>The method was evaluated using manually curated gold standard labels from the 3 National Institutes of Health cohorts. We evaluated both the intracohort and intercohort variable harmonization performance. The supervised SONAR method outperformed existing benchmark methods for almost all intracohort and intercohort comparisons using area under the curve and top-k accuracy metrics. Notably, SONAR was able to significantly improve harmonization of concepts that were difficult for existing semantic methods to harmonize.</p><p><b>CONCLUSIONS: </b>SONAR achieves accurate variable harmonization within and between cohort studies by harnessing the complementary strengths of semantic learning and variable distribution learning.</p>
</div>
<div class="hwp-text-block">
<p><b>BACKGROUND: </b>Cohort studies contain rich clinical data across large and diverse patient populations and are a common source of observational data for clinical research. Because large scale cohort studies are both time and resource intensive, one alternative is to harmonize data from existing cohorts through multicohort studies. However, given differences in variable encoding, accurate variable harmonization is difficult.</p><p><b>OBJECTIVE: </b>We propose SONAR (Semantic and Distribution-Based Harmonization) as a method for harmonizing variables across cohort studies to facilitate multicohort studies.</p><p><b>METHODS: </b>SONAR used semantic learning from variable descriptions and distribution learning from study participant data. Our method learned an embedding vector for each variable and used pairwise cosine similarity to score the similarity between variables. This approach was built off 3 National Institutes of Health cohorts, including the Cardiovascular Health Study, the Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis, and the Women's Health Initiative. We also used gold standard labels to further refine the embeddings in a supervised manner.</p><p><b>RESULTS: </b>The method was evaluated using manually curated gold standard labels from the 3 National Institutes of Health cohorts. We evaluated both the intracohort and intercohort variable harmonization performance. The supervised SONAR method outperformed existing benchmark methods for almost all intracohort and intercohort comparisons using area under the curve and top-k accuracy metrics. Notably, SONAR was able to significantly improve harmonization of concepts that were difficult for existing semantic methods to harmonize.</p><p><b>CONCLUSIONS: </b>SONAR achieves accurate variable harmonization within and between cohort studies by harnessing the complementary strengths of semantic learning and variable distribution learning.</p>
</div>
</div>
<ul class="hwp-citation__ctas">
<li class="expand-button-wrap">
<button aria-controls="hwp-citation-body-content-2086817716" aria-expanded="false" class="hwp-text-link hwp-text-link--icon-left hwp-citation__full-body-expand js-hwp-citation__full-body-expand">
<span aria-hidden="true" class="material-icon material-icon--show">add_circle</span>
<span aria-hidden="true" class="material-icon material-icon--hide">do_not_disturb_on</span>

</button>

<!-- Source: avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/publication/varppud-variant-post-prioritization-developed-undiagnosed-genetic-disorders -->
<h1>VarPPUD: Variant post prioritization developed for undiagnosed genetic disorders. | Avillach Lab</h1>
<div class='source-url'><a href='https://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/publication/varppud-variant-post-prioritization-developed-undiagnosed-genetic-disorders'>avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/publication/varppud-variant-post-prioritization-developed-undiagnosed-genetic-disorders</a></div>
<main aria-labelledby="page-title" id="main-content" lang="en" role="main" tabindex="-1">
<div class="layout-content">
<div>
<div class="hidden" data-drupal-messages-fallback=""></div>
<div class="biblio-details">
<div class="hwp-page-title bibcite-reference" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
<h1 class="text-large">
      VarPPUD: Variant post prioritization developed for undiagnosed genetic disorders.
    </h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="md:hwp-pt-64">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px max-lg:hwp-px-0">
<div class="publication-info" data-component-name="publication-info">
<div class="publication-info__image">
</div>
<div class="publication-info__text">
<h4 class="h4 hwp-mb-8">Publication information:</h4>
<div class="publication-info__body">
<div class="bibcite-citation">
<div class="csl-bib-body"><div class="csl-entry"><div class="csl-left-margin">Yin R, Gutierrez A, Network UD, Kobren SN, Avillach P. VarPPUD: Variant post prioritization developed for undiagnosed genetic disorders.</div><div class="csl-right-inline">medRxiv : the preprint server for health sciences. 2024; PMID: 38699371</div></div></div>
</div>
</div>
<ul class="publication-info__actions">
<li>
<div class="button-dropdown" data-component-name="button-dropdown">
<button class="hwp-text-link hwp-text-link--icon-left" id="publication_citation_download">
<span aria-hidden="true" class="material-icon">download_for_offline</span>
<span class="hwp-text-link__text">Download citation</span>
</button>
<ul aria-labelledby="publication_citation_download" class="button-dropdown__items" role="menu">
<li role="menuitem">
<a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773916&amp;format=bibtex">BibTeX</a>
</li>
<li role="menuitem">
<a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773916&amp;format=endnote8">EndNote X3 XML</a>
</li>
<li role="menuitem">
<a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773916&amp;format=endnote7">EndNote 7 XML</a>
</li>
<li role="menuitem">
<a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773916&amp;format=tagged">Endnote tagged</a>
</li>
<li role="menuitem">
<a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773916&amp;format=marc">Marc</a>
</li>
<li role="menuitem">
<a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773916&amp;format=pubmed_id">PubMedId</a>
</li>
<li role="menuitem">
<a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773916&amp;format=ris">RIS</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-pt-32 hwp-pb-64 md:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-citations-group">
<h3 class="h3 hwp-mb-24">Abstract</h3>
<div class="hwp-citations-group__inner">
<div class="hwp-citation hwp-citation--text-trim hwp-bg-light-base js-hwp-citation" data-component-name="citation">
<div class="hwp-citation__text">
<div class="hwp-text-block__default-text">
<p>Rare and ultra-rare genetic conditions are estimated to impact nearly 1 in 17 people worldwide, yet accurately pinpointing the diagnostic variants underlying each of these conditions remains a formidable challenge. Because comprehensive,  functional assessment of all possible genetic variants is infeasible, clinicians instead consider  variant pathogenicity predictions to distinguish plausibly disease-causing from benign variants across the genome. However, in the most difficult undiagnosed cases, such as those accepted to the Undiagnosed Diseases Network (UDN), existing pathogenicity predictions cannot reliably discern true etiological variant(s) from other deleterious candidate variants that were prioritized through N-of-1 efforts. Pinpointing the disease-causing variant from a pool of plausible candidates remains a largely manual effort requiring extensive clinical workups, functional and experimental assays, and eventual identification of genotype- and phenotype-matched individuals. Here, we introduce VarPPUD, a tool trained on prioritized variants from UDN cases, that leverages gene-, amino acid-, and nucleotide-level features to discern pathogenic variants from other deleterious variants that are unlikely to be confirmed as disease relevant. VarPPUD achieves a cross-validated accuracy of 79.3% and precision of 77.5% on a held-out subset of uniquely challenging UDN cases, respectively representing an average 18.6% and 23.4% improvement over nine traditional pathogenicity prediction approaches on this task. We validate VarPPUD's ability to discriminate likely from unlikely pathogenic variants on synthetic, GAN-generated candidate variants as well. Finally, we show how VarPPUD can be probed to evaluate each input feature's importance and contribution toward prediction-an essential step toward understanding the distinct characteristics of newly-uncovered disease-causing variants.</p>
</div>
<div class="hwp-text-block">
<p>Rare and ultra-rare genetic conditions are estimated to impact nearly 1 in 17 people worldwide, yet accurately pinpointing the diagnostic variants underlying each of these conditions remains a formidable challenge. Because comprehensive,  functional assessment of all possible genetic variants is infeasible, clinicians instead consider  variant pathogenicity predictions to distinguish plausibly disease-causing from benign variants across the genome. However, in the most difficult undiagnosed cases, such as those accepted to the Undiagnosed Diseases Network (UDN), existing pathogenicity predictions cannot reliably discern true etiological variant(s) from other deleterious candidate variants that were prioritized through N-of-1 efforts. Pinpointing the disease-causing variant from a pool of plausible candidates remains a largely manual effort requiring extensive clinical workups, functional and experimental assays, and eventual identification of genotype- and phenotype-matched individuals. Here, we introduce VarPPUD, a tool trained on prioritized variants from UDN cases, that leverages gene-, amino acid-, and nucleotide-level features to discern pathogenic variants from other deleterious variants that are unlikely to be confirmed as disease relevant. VarPPUD achieves a cross-validated accuracy of 79.3% and precision of 77.5% on a held-out subset of uniquely challenging UDN cases, respectively representing an average 18.6% and 23.4% improvement over nine traditional pathogenicity prediction approaches on this task. We validate VarPPUD's ability to discriminate likely from unlikely pathogenic variants on synthetic, GAN-generated candidate variants as well. Finally, we show how VarPPUD can be probed to evaluate each input feature's importance and contribution toward prediction-an essential step toward understanding the distinct characteristics of newly-uncovered disease-causing variants.</p>
</div>
</div>
<ul class="hwp-citation__ctas">
<li class="expand-button-wrap">
<button aria-controls="hwp-citation-body-content-2000961178" aria-expanded="false" class="hwp-text-link hwp-text-link--icon-left hwp-citation__full-body-expand js-hwp-citation__full-body-expand">
<span aria-hidden="true" class="material-icon material-icon--show">add_circle</span>
<span aria-hidden="true" class="material-icon material-icon--hide">do_not_disturb_on</span>
<span class="hwp-text-link__text">Abstract</span>
</button>
</li>

</div>

<!-- Source: avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/autism-pilot -->
<h1>Autism Pilot | Avillach Lab</h1>
<div class='source-url'><a href='https://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/autism-pilot'>avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/autism-pilot</a></div>
<main aria-label="Autism Pilot" aria-labelledby="page-title" id="main-content" lang="en" role="main" tabindex="-1">
<div class="layout-content">
<div>
<div class="hidden" data-drupal-messages-fallback=""></div>
<article class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
<h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
<span>Autism Pilot</span>
</h1>
</div>

<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64">

<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>	BCH internally-funded Gene partnership / Research Connection</p><p>	Co-Investigator ($800k) (PI: Isaac Kohane)</p><p>	Creating a comprehensive autism clinical and genomic database using an i2b2-based research platform: tranSMART</p></div>

<!-- Source: avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/exploring-and-understanding-adverse-drug-reactions-integrative-mining-clinical-records -->
<h1>Exploring and Understanding Adverse Drug Reactions by Integrative Mining of Clinical Records and Biomedical Knowledge | Avillach Lab</h1>
<div class='source-url'><a href='https://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/exploring-and-understanding-adverse-drug-reactions-integrative-mining-clinical-records'>avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/exploring-and-understanding-adverse-drug-reactions-integrative-mining-clinical-records</a></div>
<main aria-label="Exploring and Understanding Adverse Drug Reactions by Integrative Mining of Clinical Records and Biomedical Knowledge" aria-labelledby="page-title" id="main-content" lang="en" role="main" tabindex="-1">
<div class="layout-content">
<div>
<div class="hidden" data-drupal-messages-fallback=""></div>
<article class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
<h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
<span>Exploring and Understanding Adverse Drug Reactions by Integrative Mining of Clinical Records and Biomedical Knowledge</span>
</h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>	FP7 - European Commission grant #215847 - <a href="http://www.euadr-project.org">http://www.euadr-project.org</a></p><p>	Site co-PI and leader of one specific aim (out of 8 in the project) ($266,000) (Total project: $8 million) (PI: Johan Van der Lei)</p><p>	Develop an innovative computerized system to detect adverse drug reactions supplementing spontaneous reporting systems. To achieve this objective, EU-ADR exploited clinical data from electronic healthcare records (EHRs) of over 30 million patients from several European countries.Â </p></div>
<div class="hwp-news-footer hwp-py-24 hwp-pt-0 hwp-container hwp-container-px">

<!-- Source: avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/randomized-control-study-impact-computerized-prescription-entry-drug-prescription -->
<h1>Randomized control study on the impact of computerized prescription entry on drug prescription by undergraduate medical students | Avillach Lab</h1>
<div class='source-url'><a href='https://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/randomized-control-study-impact-computerized-prescription-entry-drug-prescription'>avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/randomized-control-study-impact-computerized-prescription-entry-drug-prescription</a></div>
<main aria-label="Randomized control study on the impact of computerized prescription entry on drug prescription by undergraduate medical students" aria-labelledby="page-title" id="main-content" lang="en" role="main" tabindex="-1">
<div class="layout-content">
<div>
<div class="hidden" data-drupal-messages-fallback=""></div>
<article class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
<h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
<span>Randomized control study on the impact of computerized prescription entry on drug prescription by undergraduate medical students</span>
</h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>	University Paris Descartes innovative grant in pedagogy</p><p>	PI ($7,000)</p><p>	Students in their final year of medical studies learn, in addition to theoretical education faculty, prescription real world "bedside" with supervision by senior physicians. The assumption is that the formalization of an entire prescription with the support of electronic prescribing, under the supervision of a senior to explain the mistakes, is a new educational tool for learning prescritpion in front of the patient bed. We performed a randomized controlled trail to measure the impact on improving the prescribing knowledge.</p></div>
<div class="hwp-news-footer hwp-py-24 hwp-pt-0 hwp-container hwp-container-px">
<div class="page-tags">
<span class="hwp-mb-16 hwp-block">See also:</span>
<ul class="hwp-news-footer__tags hwp-flex hwp-flex-wrap hwp-gap-16 hwp-mb-24">
<li class="max-sm:hwp-w-full">
<a class="hwp-button-tag hwp-button-tag--dark" href="/research/past">
              Past
            </a>
</li>

<!-- Source: avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/nihncats-global-rare-diseases-patient-registry-i2b2transmart-data-repository -->
<h1>NIH/NCATS Global Rare Diseases Patient Registry i2b2/tranSMART Data Repository | Avillach Lab</h1>
<div class='source-url'><a href='https://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/nihncats-global-rare-diseases-patient-registry-i2b2transmart-data-repository'>avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/nihncats-global-rare-diseases-patient-registry-i2b2transmart-data-repository</a></div>
<main aria-label="NIH/NCATS Global Rare Diseases Patient Registry i2b2/tranSMART Data Repository" aria-labelledby="page-title" id="main-content" lang="en" role="main" tabindex="-1">
<div class="layout-content">
<div>
<div class="hidden" data-drupal-messages-fallback=""></div>
<article class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
<h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
<span>NIH/NCATS Global Rare Diseases Patient Registry i2b2/tranSMART Data Repository</span>
</h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>NIH/NCATS</p><p>Co-PI. Total:$ 2.4 M. PI: Isaac Kohane</p><p>The integration of clinical and biomedical data hosted in multiple distributed repositories is confronted by two significant challenges: i) correctly linking information pertaining to the same patient across repositories, for example, linking lab results data with bedside observations data; and ii) making data available for analysis at different locations across a collaboration network. These problems are exacerbated in the case of rare diseases research, given the very limited availability of data sets and data standards. We propose to develop the NCAT Global Repository for Rare Diseases Research (GRDR) based on BD2K PIC-SURE platform to address these challenges. NCAT GRDR repository will be a scalable, secure, and flexible integration architecture for clinical and biomedical datasets, which by extending the successful i2b2/tranSMART platform will allow data providers to easily share their data with the wider research community without requiring them to subscribe to proprietary vocabulary standards or to develop complex mapping protocols. Using federated data access and querying methods that retrieve relevant data from different locations before combining them, GRDR will make it possible for comparative analysis methods to be executed on the integrated datasets. By assigning generic identifiers (after de-identification) to related data across locations, GRDR will ease the difficulties of linking data while conforming to the requirements of patient data privacy and other security regulations. We aim to progressively integrate up to 17 multidimensional, and heterogeneous patient registries on GRDR and provide encrypted access to this data to authenticated users over a secure connection.</p></div>
<div class="hwp-news-footer hwp-py-24 hwp-pt-0 hwp-container hwp-container-px">
<div class="page-tags">
<span class="hwp-mb-16 hwp-block">See also:</span>
<ul class="hwp-news-footer__tags hwp-flex hwp-flex-wrap hwp-gap-16 hwp-mb-24">
<li class="max-sm:hwp-w-full">
<a class="hwp-button-tag hwp-button-tag--dark" href="/research/past">
              Past
            </a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</article>
</div>
</div>
</main><hr>
<!-- Source: avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/i2b2transmart-pilot-study-cloud-using-redshift-phase-i -->
<h1>i2b2/tranSMART pilot study on the cloud using Redshift - Phase I | Avillach Lab</h1>
<div class='source-url'><a href='https://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/i2b2transmart-pilot-study-cloud-using-redshift-phase-i'>avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/i2b2transmart-pilot-study-cloud-using-redshift-phase-i</a></div>
<main aria-label="i2b2/tranSMART pilot study on the cloud using Redshift - Phase I" aria-labelledby="page-title" id="main-content" lang="en" role="main" tabindex="-1">
<div class="layout-content">
<div>
<div class="hidden" data-drupal-messages-fallback=""></div>
<article class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
<h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
<span>i2b2/tranSMART pilot study on the cloud using Redshift - Phase I</span>
</h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>	Amazon Web Services Research Grant</p><p>	EDU_R_FY2015_Q2_HarvardMedicalSchool_Avillach-NEW</p><p>	PI $100K</p><p>	To handle increasing data volumes and potential new sources of data, and to promote patient engagement, we intend to conduct a pilot study that involves hosting this infrastructure on a paradigm which provides high storage, computing power and availability, AWS.</p><p>	Our project plan comprises 2 phases:</p><p>	- Phase 1 will involve transforming the open access NDAR (National Database for Autism Research) database to the i2b2/tranSMART model. The transformed NDAR and the existing Oracle databases will be ported to the AWS cloud. The computing power of AWS will be leveraged to identify comorbidities between PMS and autism patients, and correlations between clinical and genomic data.</p><p>	- Phase 2 will involve the adaptation of the i2b2 data model to Redshift Petabyte for the storage and analysis of increasing volumes of patient data. This will entail transferring NDAR phenotypic and annotated genetic data and PMS_DN data to Redshift nodes.Â </p></div>
<div class="hwp-news-footer hwp-py-24 hwp-pt-0 hwp-container hwp-container-px">
<div class="page-tags">
<span class="hwp-mb-16 hwp-block">See also:</span>
<ul class="hwp-news-footer__tags hwp-flex hwp-flex-wrap hwp-gap-16 hwp-mb-24">
<li class="max-sm:hwp-w-full">
<a class="hwp-button-tag hwp-button-tag--dark" href="/research/past">
              Past
            </a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>

<h1>Delineating autism subtypes by phenotype-wide scan across genome-wide genotypes in a patient-centric information commons | Avillach Lab</h1>
<div class='source-url'><a href='https://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/delineating-autism-subtypes-phenotype-wide-scan-across-genome-wide-genotypes-patient'>avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/delineating-autism-subtypes-phenotype-wide-scan-across-genome-wide-genotypes-patient</a></div>

<span>Delineating autism subtypes by phenotype-wide scan across genome-wide genotypes in a patient-centric information commons</span>
</h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>	Nancy Lurie Marks Foundation</p><p>	PI ($100k)</p><p>	This grant is for a one-year study that would result in a phenome-wide scan across all genotypes measured by SNP array. This will likely generate novel insights about the substructure of the different autisms.</p></div>

<!-- Source: avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/neuropsychiatric-genome-scale-and-rdoc-individualized-domains-n-grid-0 -->
<h1>Neuropsychiatric Genome-Scale and RDoC Individualized Domains (N-GRID) | Avillach Lab</h1>
<div class='source-url'><a href='https://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/neuropsychiatric-genome-scale-and-rdoc-individualized-domains-n-grid-0'>avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/neuropsychiatric-genome-scale-and-rdoc-individualized-domains-n-grid-0</a></div>
<main aria-label="Neuropsychiatric Genome-Scale and RDoC Individualized Domains (N-GRID)" aria-labelledby="page-title" id="main-content" lang="en" role="main" tabindex="-1">
<div class="layout-content">
<div>
<div class="hidden" data-drupal-messages-fallback=""></div>
<article class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
<h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
<span>Neuropsychiatric Genome-Scale and RDoC Individualized Domains (N-GRID)</span>
</h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>	NIH P50 MH106933</p><p>	Co-Investigator (PI: Isaac Kohane)</p><p>	As a result of the accelerated pace of development of technologies for characterizing the human genome, the rate-limiting step for large scale genomic investigation in clinical populations is now phenotyping. This is particularly the case for neuropsychiatric (NP) illness, where phenotypes are complex, biomarkers are lacking, and the primary cell types of interest are difficult to access directly. It has become apparent that both rare and common genetic variation contributes to disease risk and that this risk crosses traditional diagnostic boundaries in psychiatry. Taking advantage of a large, already-established NP biobank could dramatically accelerate progress toward understanding the cross-disorder mechanism of action of disease liability genes. This study proposes novel applications of emerging technologies in informatics and cellular neurobiology to eliminate this phenotyping bottleneck. In doing so, it will accelerate investigation of clinical and cellular phenoytpes for understanding single and multi-locus/polygenic associations.Â Â </p></div>
<div class="hwp-news-footer hwp-py-24 hwp-pt-0 hwp-container hwp-container-px">
<div class="page-tags">
<span class="hwp-mb-16 hwp-block">See also:</span>
<ul class="hwp-news-footer__tags hwp-flex hwp-flex-wrap hwp-gap-16 hwp-mb-24">
<li class="max-sm:hwp-w-full">
<a class="hwp-button-tag hwp-button-tag--dark" href="/research/past">
              Past
            </a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</article>
</div>

<h1>NIH/NCATS Global Rare Diseases Patient Registry i2b2/tranSMART Data Repository | Avillach Lab</h1>
<div class='source-url'><a href='https://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/nihncats-global-rare-diseases-patient-registry-i2b2transmart-data-repository-0'>avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/nihncats-global-rare-diseases-patient-registry-i2b2transmart-data-repository-0</a></div>
<main aria-label="NIH/NCATS Global Rare Diseases Patient Registry i2b2/tranSMART Data Repository" aria-labelledby="page-title" id="main-content" lang="en" role="main" tabindex="-1">
<div class="layout-content">
<div>
<div class="hidden" data-drupal-messages-fallback=""></div>
<article class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">

<h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
<span>NIH/NCATS Global Rare Diseases Patient Registry i2b2/tranSMART Data Repository</span>
</h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>NIH/NCATS</p><p>Co-PIÂ  Total $2.4MÂ  (PI: Isaac Kohane)</p><p>The integration of clinical and biomedical data hosted in multiple distributed repositories is confonted by two significant challenges: 1) correctly linking information pertaining to the same patient across repositories, for example, linking lab results data with bedside observations data; and 2) making data available for analysis at different locations across a collaboration network. These problems are exacerbated in the case of rare diseases research, given the very limited availability of data sets and data standards. We propose to develop the NCAT Global Repository for Rare Diseases Research (GRDR) based on BD2K PIC-SURE platform to address these challenges. NCAT GRDR repository will be a scalable, secure, and flexible integration architecture for clinical and biomedical datasets, which by extending the successful i2b2/tranSMART platform will allow data providers to easily share their data with the wider research community without requiring them to subscribe to proprietary vocabulary standards or to develop complex mapping protocols. Using federated data access and querying methods that retrieve relevant data from different locations before combining them, GRDR will make it possible for comparative analysis methods to be executed on the integrated datasets. By assigning generic identifiers (after de-identification) to related data across locations, GRDR will ease the difficulties of linking data while conforming to the requirements of patient data privacy and other security regulations. We aim to progressively integrate up to 17 multidimensional, and heterogeneous patient registries on GRDR and provide encrypted access to this data to authenticated users over a secure connection.Â </p></div>

<!-- Source: avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/evaluating-scalability-packaged-open-source-biomedical-informatics-applications-across-2 -->
<h1>Evaluating the scalability of packaged open source biomedical informatics applications across cloud based providers - Phase II | Avillach Lab</h1>
<div class='source-url'><a href='https://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/evaluating-scalability-packaged-open-source-biomedical-informatics-applications-across-2'>avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/evaluating-scalability-packaged-open-source-biomedical-informatics-applications-across-2</a></div>
<main aria-label="Evaluating the scalability of packaged open source biomedical informatics applications across cloud based providers - Phase II" aria-labelledby="page-title" id="main-content" lang="en" role="main" tabindex="-1">
<div class="layout-content">
<div>
<div class="hidden" data-drupal-messages-fallback=""></div>
<article class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
<h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
<span>Evaluating the scalability of packaged open source biomedical informatics applications across cloud based providers - Phase II</span>
</h1>
</div>
</div>

<!-- Source: avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/i2b2transmart-pilot-study-cloud-using-redshift-phase-ii -->
<h1>i2b2/tranSMART pilot study on the cloud using Redshift - Phase II | Avillach Lab</h1>
<div class='source-url'><a href='https://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/i2b2transmart-pilot-study-cloud-using-redshift-phase-ii'>avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/i2b2transmart-pilot-study-cloud-using-redshift-phase-ii</a></div>
<main aria-label="i2b2/tranSMART pilot study on the cloud using Redshift - Phase II" aria-labelledby="page-title" id="main-content" lang="en" role="main" tabindex="-1">
<div class="layout-content">
<div>
<div class="hidden" data-drupal-messages-fallback=""></div>
<article class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
<h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
<span>i2b2/tranSMART pilot study on the cloud using Redshift - Phase II</span>
</h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>	Amazon Web Services Research</p><p>	Grant EDU_R_FY2016</p><p>	PI $55K</p><p>	To handle increasing data volumes and potential new sources of data, and to promote patient engagement, we intend to conduct a pilot study that involves hosting this infrastructure on a paradigm which provides high storage, computing power and availability, AWS.</p><p>	Our project plan comprises 2 phases:</p><p>	- Phase 1 will involve transforming the open access NDAR (National Database for Autism Research) database to the i2b2/tranSMART model. The transformed NDAR and the existing Oracle databases will be ported to the AWS cloud. The computing power of AWS will be leveraged to identify comorbidities between PMS and autism patients, and correlations between clinical and genomic data.</p><p>	- Phase 2 will involve the adaptation of the i2b2 data model to Redshift Petabyte for the storage and analysis of increasing volumes of patient data. This will entail transferring NDAR phenotypic and annotated genetic data and PMS_DN data to Redshift nodes.Â </p></div>
<div class="hwp-news-footer hwp-py-24 hwp-pt-0 hwp-container hwp-container-px">
<div class="page-tags">
<span class="hwp-mb-16 hwp-block">See also:</span>
<ul class="hwp-news-footer__tags hwp-flex hwp-flex-wrap hwp-gap-16 hwp-mb-24">
<li class="max-sm:hwp-w-full">
<a class="hwp-button-tag hwp-button-tag--dark" href="/research/past">
              Past
            </a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

</div>

<h1>Center for Causal Modeling and Discovery of Biomedical Knowledge from Big Data (CCD) - Phase II | Avillach Lab</h1>
<div class='source-url'><a href='https://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/center-causal-modeling-and-discovery-biomedical-knowledge-big-data-ccd-phase-ii'>avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/center-causal-modeling-and-discovery-biomedical-knowledge-big-data-ccd-phase-ii</a></div>
<main aria-label="Center for Causal Modeling and Discovery of Biomedical Knowledge from Big Data (CCD) - Phase II" aria-labelledby="page-title" id="main-content" lang="en" role="main" tabindex="-1">
<div class="layout-content">
<div>
<div class="hidden" data-drupal-messages-fallback=""></div>
<article class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
<h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
<span>Center for Causal Modeling and Discovery of Biomedical Knowledge from Big Data (CCD) - Phase II</span>
</h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>	NIH BD2K Admin Supplement 3U54HG008540-03S1</p><p>	Co-investigator (PI: Cooper Greg, University of Pittsburgh)</p><p>	The Center for Causal Modeling and Discovery of Biomedical Knowledge from Big Data (CCD) and the Patient-centered Information Commons (PIC-SURE) will collaborate to develop a system that shares data, and computational accessibility in an externally hosted environment (i.e., cloud). We will start by developing a standardized RESTful Application-Programming-Interface (API) that will enable our organizations to share data and the analysis results. This will serve as providing the base for other BD2K centers and organizations to share data and services in the future.Â </p></div>
<div class="hwp-news-footer hwp-py-24 hwp-pt-0 hwp-container hwp-container-px">

Enable trial eligibility and recruitment criteria to be expressed in ways that permit searching for relevant patients across EHR distributed systems, and confidentially initiate participation requests via the patients' authorized clinicians.Â </p></div>

<h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
<span>BCH Precision Link - Genomics Research and Innovation Network (GRIN)</span>
</h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>Boston Children's Hospital (BCH), Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center (CCHMC), Children's Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP)</p><p>Co-Investigator BCHÂ  Total: $6MÂ  PI BCH: Ken Mandl</p><p>To accelerate genomic discovery, collaboration, and improved clinical outcomes, research leaders at Boston Children's Hospital (BCH), Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center (CCHMC), and Children's Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP) have come together to propose the creation of the Genomics Research and Innovation Network (GRIN).Â </p><p>Four major potential uses of the GRIN resource, including:</p><p>1) Facilitating cohort expansion - especially valuable in the study of rare disease</p><p>2) Creation of a broad knowledgebase for variant interpretation</p><p>3) Matching junior investigators to clinical and research expertise</p><p>4) Matching investigators to expertise and resources for functional studies and animal models</p></div>

<h1>I2b2 Clinical Data Warehouse (CDW) implementation at HÃ´pital EuropÃ©en Georges Pompidou - APHP, Paris, France | Avillach Lab</h1>

<h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
<span>I2b2 Clinical Data Warehouse (CDW) implementation at HÃ´pital EuropÃ©en Georges Pompidou - APHP, Paris, France</span>
</h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>	Hospital internally funded</p><p>	Co-PI ($200,000) (PI: Patrice Degoulet)</p><p>	The i2b2 CDW allows reuse of computerized data of patients for achieving cohorts. The health information on 606,000 patients with diagnoses, symptoms, medical procedures, drug therapy, etc. for 13 years were made available for research.Â </p></div>

<h1>EMIF: European Medical Information Framework | Avillach Lab</h1>
<div class='source-url'><a href='https://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/emif-european-medical-information-framework-0'>avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/emif-european-medical-information-framework-0</a></div>
<main aria-label="EMIF: European Medical Information Framework" aria-labelledby="page-title" id="main-content" lang="en" role="main" tabindex="-1">
<div class="layout-content">
<div>
<div class="hidden" data-drupal-messages-fallback=""></div>
<article class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
<h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
<span>EMIF: European Medical Information Framework</span>
</h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>	IMI European Commission: Grant No 115372 <a href="http://www.imi.europa.eu/content/emif">http://www.imi.europa.eu/content/emif</a></p><p>	Site PI and Task Leader ($250K) (total project: $74 million) (PI: Simon Lovestone / Johan van der Lei)</p><p>	Generating a common patient health information framework addressing the two research topics: Obesity and its metabolic complications; and Markers for the development of Alzheimer's disease (AD) and other dementias. Existing human health data sources that are within scope of EMIF can be grouped into three types: 1) General-purpose-collected EHR data - 52 million patients across Europe, 2) Cohort data and 3) Biobanks</p></div>
<div class="hwp-news-footer hwp-py-24 hwp-pt-0 hwp-container hwp-container-px">
<div class="page-tags">
<span class="hwp-mb-16 hwp-block">See also:</span>

<a class="hwp-button-tag hwp-button-tag--dark" href="/research/past">

<!-- Source: avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/patient-centered-information-commons-0 -->
<h1>Patient-Centered Information Commons | Avillach Lab</h1>
<div class='source-url'><a href='https://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/patient-centered-information-commons-0'>avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/patient-centered-information-commons-0</a></div>
<main aria-label="Patient-Centered Information Commons" aria-labelledby="page-title" id="main-content" lang="en" role="main" tabindex="-1">
<div class="layout-content">
<div>
<div class="hidden" data-drupal-messages-fallback=""></div>
<article class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
<h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
<span>Patient-Centered Information Commons</span>
</h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>	NIH/BD2K U54 HG007963</p><p>	Co-Investigator (PI: Isaac Kohane)</p><p>	We propose to create a massively scalable toolkit to enable large, multi-center Patient-centered Informatic Commons (PIC) at loval, regional, and national scale, where the focus is the alignment of all available biomedical data per individual. Such a Commons is a prerequisite for conducting the large-N, Big Data, longitudinal studies essential for understanding causation in the Precision Medicine framework while simultaneously addressing key complexities of Patient Centric Outcome Research studies required under ACA (Affordable Care Act).</p></div>
<div class="hwp-news-footer hwp-py-24 hwp-pt-0 hwp-container hwp-container-px">
<div class="page-tags">

<a class="hwp-button-tag hwp-button-tag--dark" href="/research/past">
              Past
            </a>
</li>
</ul>

<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>The Cure Sickle Cell Initiative is a collaborative, patient-focused research eï¬ort designed to accelerate promising genetic therapies to cure sickle cell disease. The Initiative considers non-traditional ways to advance research and brings together the sickle cell disease (SCD) communityâpatients, advocates, caregivers, providers, researchers, industry, and others.</p></div>

<h1>NHLBI BioData Catalyst | Avillach Lab</h1>
<div class='source-url'><a href='https://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/nhlbi-biodatacatalyst'>avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/nhlbi-biodatacatalyst</a></div>
<main aria-label="NHLBI BioData Catalyst" aria-labelledby="page-title" id="main-content" lang="en" role="main" tabindex="-1">
<div class="layout-content">
<div>
<div class="hidden" data-drupal-messages-fallback=""></div>
<article class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
<h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
<span>NHLBI BioData Catalyst</span>
</h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>NHLBI BioData CatalystÂ® (BDC) is a cloud-based platform providing tools, applications, and workflows in secure workspaces. By increasing access to NHLBI datasets and innovative data analysis capabilities, BDC accelerates efficient biomedical research that drives discovery and scientific advancement, leading to novel diagnostic tools, therapeutics, and prevention strategies for heart, lung, blood, and sleep disorders.</p><p>Though the primary goal of the BDC project is to build a data science ecosystem, at its core, this is a people-centric endeavor. BDC is also building a community of practice working collaboratively to solve technical and scientific challenges.</p><p><a href="https://biodatacatalyst.nhlbi.nih.gov/">https://biodatacatalyst.nhlbi.nih.gov/</a></p><p>Explore hosted data on <em>BDC Powered by PIC-SURE</em>: <a href="https://picsure.biodatacatalyst.nhlbi.nih.gov/">https://picsure.biodatacatalyst.nhlbi.nih.gov/</a>Â </p></div>
<div class="hwp-news-footer hwp-py-24 hwp-pt-0 hwp-container hwp-container-px">

<h1>Scalable Collaborative Infrastructure for a Learning Healthcare System (SCILHS) - Phase II | Avillach Lab</h1>
<div class='source-url'><a href='https://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/scalable-collaborative-infrastructure-learning-healthcare-system-scilhs-phase-ii'>avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/scalable-collaborative-infrastructure-learning-healthcare-system-scilhs-phase-ii</a></div>
<main aria-label="Scalable Collaborative Infrastructure for a Learning Healthcare System (SCILHS) - Phase II" aria-labelledby="page-title" id="main-content" lang="en" role="main" tabindex="-1">
<div class="layout-content">
<div>
<div class="hidden" data-drupal-messages-fallback=""></div>
<article class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
<h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
<span>Scalable Collaborative Infrastructure for a Learning Healthcare System (SCILHS) - Phase II</span>
</h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>	PCOR - CDRN</p><p>	Co-Investigator (PI: Ken Mandl)</p><p>	Leveraging an informatics infrastructure that our investigators have developed over the past 15 years, the Department of Biomedical Informatics (DBMI) at Harvard Medical School will work across 10 healthcare centers throughout the U.S. to develop the Scalable Collaborative Infrastructure for a Learning Health System (SCILHS, pronounced "skills"). An open-source platform, the system will cover more than 8 million patients and enable clinician and patient participation in research.Â </p></div>

<h1>PCORI PPRN - Phelan McDermid Syndrome Data Network (PMS_DN) Phase II | Avillach Lab</h1>
<div class='source-url'><a href='https://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/pcori-pprn-phelan-mcdermid-syndrome-data-network-pmsdn-phase-ii'>avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/pcori-pprn-phelan-mcdermid-syndrome-data-network-pmsdn-phase-ii</a></div>
<main aria-label="PCORI PPRN - Phelan McDermid Syndrome Data Network (PMS_DN) Phase II" aria-labelledby="page-title" id="main-content" lang="en" role="main" tabindex="-1">
<div class="layout-content">
<div>
<div class="hidden" data-drupal-messages-fallback=""></div>
<article class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
<h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
<span>PCORI PPRN - Phelan McDermid Syndrome Data Network (PMS_DN) Phase II</span>
</h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>Co-PI ($1.2M) Total $1.6M (PI: Megan O'Boyle from <a href="http://22q13.org/j15/">PMSF</a>)</p><p><a href="http://www.pcori.org/research-results/2013/phelan-mcdermid-syndrome-data-network">Phelan McDermid Syndrome Data Network (PMS_DN): A PCORI Patient Powered Research Network</a></p><p>The PMS_DN mission is to advance knowledge, care, and treatment of Phelan-McDermid Syndrome (PMS), and related conditions by integrating diverse, complex datasets from multiple sources into a richly populated, high quality, and accessible centralized database to facilitate patient-centered research. The network promotes a culture of transparency and authentic engagement and leadership of families in network vision, governance, and generation of research priorities. The organizations participating in the PMS_DN include: The Phelan McDermid Syndrome Foundation (PMSF), the Department of Biomedical Informatics at Harvard Medical School (HMS), and Boston Children's Hospital</p></div>
<div class="hwp-news-footer hwp-py-24 hwp-pt-0 hwp-container hwp-container-px">
<div class="page-tags">
<span class="hwp-mb-16 hwp-block">See also:</span>

<a class="hwp-button-tag hwp-button-tag--dark" href="/research/past">
              Past
            </a>

<h1>NHLBI/NIH Data Fusion - A Self-Scaling, Open Source Registry Advancing Pediatric Pulmonary Vascular Disease Research | Avillach Lab</h1>
<div class='source-url'><a href='https://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/nhlbinih-data-fusion-self-scaling-open-source-registry-advancing-pediatric-pulmonary-vascular'>avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/nhlbinih-data-fusion-self-scaling-open-source-registry-advancing-pediatric-pulmonary-vascular</a></div>

<h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
<span>NHLBI/NIH Data Fusion - A Self-Scaling, Open Source Registry Advancing Pediatric Pulmonary Vascular Disease Research</span>
</h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>3U01HL121518-02S1</p><p>Co-Investigator (PI: Mandl/Abman)</p><p>We will enhance a registry of children with pulmonary hypertension by improving the quality of data on medications and adverse events. Our approach leverages uniquely valuable data from pharmacies as well as computerized reading and interpretation of free text clinician notes.Â </p></div>

<!-- Source: avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/nihncats-global-rare-diseases-patient-registry-data-repository-grdr%C2%AE -->
<h1>NIH/NCATS Global Rare Diseases Patient Registry Data Repository (GRDRÂ®) | Avillach Lab</h1>
<div class='source-url'><a href='https://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/nihncats-global-rare-diseases-patient-registry-data-repository-grdr%C2%AE'>avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/nihncats-global-rare-diseases-patient-registry-data-repository-grdr%C2%AE</a></div>
<main aria-label="NIH/NCATS Global Rare Diseases Patient Registry Data Repository (GRDRÂ®)" aria-labelledby="page-title" id="main-content" lang="en" role="main" tabindex="-1">
<div class="layout-content">
<div>
<div class="hidden" data-drupal-messages-fallback=""></div>
<article class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
<h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
<span>NIH/NCATS Global Rare Diseases Patient Registry Data Repository (GRDRÂ®)</span>
</h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>This is a web-based resource that aggregates, secures, and stores deidentified patient information from 12 different registries for rare diseases (5,277 patients with 178 different rare dieseases) all in one place. This platform allows for the wider dissemination of data collected by individual rare disease registries as well as the increased accessibility of data for researchers conducting intra-registry and cross-registry queries in the genesis of hypotheses for potential study. It uses the BD2K PIC-SURE RESTful API international ontologies for semantic interoperability, mappings to UMLS Concept Unique Identifiers, and mappings to 55 different GRDR Common Data Elements.</p><p>Â </p><p dir="ltr"><strong>10 Minute Demo Video:Â </strong><a href="https://vimeo.com/151171529">https://vimeo.com/151171529</a>Â </p><p dir="ltr">Â </p></div>
<div class="hwp-news-footer hwp-py-24 hwp-pt-0 hwp-container hwp-container-px">
<div class="page-tags">
<span class="hwp-mb-16 hwp-block">See also:</span>
<ul class="hwp-news-footer__tags hwp-flex hwp-flex-wrap hwp-gap-16 hwp-mb-24">
<li class="max-sm:hwp-w-full">
<a class="hwp-button-tag hwp-button-tag--dark" href="/access-data/restricted-data-access">
              Restricted Data Access
            </a>
</li>
<li class="max-sm:hwp-w-full">
<a class="hwp-button-tag hwp-button-tag--dark" href="/research/past">
              Past
            </a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</article>
</div>
</div>
</main><hr>
<!-- Source: avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/pcori-pprn-phelan-mcdermid-syndrome-data-network -->
<h1>PCORI PPRN - Phelan-McDermid Syndrome Data Network | Avillach Lab</h1>
<div class='source-url'><a href='https://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/pcori-pprn-phelan-mcdermid-syndrome-data-network'>avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/pcori-pprn-phelan-mcdermid-syndrome-data-network</a></div>
<main aria-label="PCORI PPRN - Phelan-McDermid Syndrome Data Network" aria-labelledby="page-title" id="main-content" lang="en" role="main" tabindex="-1">
<div class="layout-content">
<div>
<div class="hidden" data-drupal-messages-fallback=""></div>
<article class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
<h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
<span>PCORI PPRN - Phelan-McDermid Syndrome Data Network</span>
</h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>Co-PI ($624K)Â  Total $950K Â  (PI Â Megan O'Boyle fromÂ <a href="http://22q13.org/j15/">PMSF</a> )<br/>PCORI - PPRNÂ <a href="http://www.pcori.org/research-results/2013/phelan-mcdermid-syndrome-data-network">http://www.pcori.org/research-results/2013/phelan-mcdermid-syndrome-data-network</a></p><p><span>Â The PMS_DN mission is to advance knowledge, care, and treatment of Phelan-McDermid Syndrome (PMS) and related conditions by integrating diverse, complex data sources into a richly populated, high quality, and accessible centralized database to facilitate patient-centered research. The network promotes a culture of transparency and authentic engagement and leadership of families in network vision, governance, and generation of research priorities. The organizations participating in the PMS_DN include: The Phelan-McDermid Syndrome Foundation, the Harvard Medical School (HMS) Department of Biomedical Informatics, and Boston Childrenâs Hospital.</span><br/>Â </p><p><span>PMS, a rare genetic condition caused by errors on the end of chromosome 22 (22q13), is associated with autism/autism spectrum disorders, intellectual disabilities, sleep disorders, and seizures. There is no treatment for PMS. There are ~1,100 </span><em><span>diagnosed cases</span></em><span> worldwide, with at least 520 cases confirmed in the US. However, a conservative estimate, regardless if known/diagnosed, is 8,898 US cases. Since PMS_DNâs launch in July 2014, 281 families have consented to participate in the network and PCORnet studies (~50% of known US diagnosed cases). The PMS_DNâs enrollment target for Phase II is 400 US cases (~75% of known US diagnosed cases). PCORnet offers a vital opportunity to advance knowledge and care for PMS, capitalizing on the consortium to enroll families in observational studies and pragmatic clinical trials, while identifying undiagnosed individuals and connecting families to needed services. The PMS_DN brings unique assets to PCORnet: an established data portal for collecting patient-reported outcomes (PROs), the PMS International Registry (PMSIR), and i2b2/tranSMART, a platform that allows researchers to analyze complex data types harmonized to the PCORnet Common Data Model (CDM) v2 and enables integration of PROs with validated knowledge extracted from EHR clinical notes through Natural Language Processing (NLP).</span></p><p><span>The PMS_DN integrates PROs with data from the application of NLP to EHR clinical notes submitted by families. The technical platform to achieve this integration and harmonize data domains with the current version of the PCORnet CDM is i2b2/tranSMART. The PMS_DN completed a mapping file for PRO data that has been validated with real patient data and production of an audit trail of the clinical data integration pipeline in tranSMART. An advantage of i2b2/tranSMART is that an investigator can quickly validate outcomes of interest from the output of the NLP with the i2b2/tranSMART interface, viewing all anonymized sentences from which the concept was generated. The network uses cTAKES including a new temporal module that extracts time and event concepts from clinical notes, enabling a complete longitudinal view of a patient. The PMS_DN maps to several ontologies/terminologies: SNOMED CT, ICD9, ICD10, Human Phenotype Ontology, Gene Ontology, and MeSH.</span></p><div class="hwp-media hwp-media--full-width">
<div class="field field--name-field-media-image field--type-image field--label-hidden"> <img alt="capture_decran_2014-05-06_21.04.15.png" height="664" loading="lazy" src="/sites/g/files/omnuum4001/files/avillach_lab/files/capture_decran_2014-05-06_21.04.15_0.png" width="1000"/>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-news-footer hwp-py-24 hwp-pt-0 hwp-container hwp-container-px">
<div class="page-tags">
<span class="hwp-mb-16 hwp-block">See also:</span>
<ul class="hwp-news-footer__tags hwp-flex hwp-flex-wrap hwp-gap-16 hwp-mb-24">
<li class="max-sm:hwp-w-full">
<a class="hwp-button-tag hwp-button-tag--dark" href="/research/past">
              Past
            </a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</article>
</div>
</div>
</main><hr>

<article class="page-card page-card--horizontal page-card--hwp-person page-card--teaser hwp-bg-light-base" data-component-name="page-card" lang="en">
<div class="page-card__text hwp-order-1">
<a class="page-card__link hwp-order-2" href="/people/yuri-ahuja"> <h3 class="page-card__heading hwp-order-2">Yuri Ahuja</h3>
</a>
<a class="page-card__email hwp-order-3" href="mailto:yuri_ahuja@hms.harvard.edu">yuri_ahuja@hms.harvard.edu</a>
<div class="page-card__subheading hwp-order-2">
<div class="field field--name-field-hwp-person-prof-title field--type-string field--label-hidden">
<div>MD/PhD Candidate at Harvard Medical School</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="page-card__image page-card__image--4-5">
<div class="page-card__thumb">
<div class="hwp-media hwp-media--4-5-person-list-no-caption">

<h1>2014-07 PRESS RELEASE - TranSmart Informatics Platform to be Used in $1M Phelan-McDermid Syndrome Research Project | Avillach Lab</h1>
<div class='source-url'><a href='https://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/press-release-transmart-informatics-platform-be-used-1m-phelan-mcdermid-syndrome'>avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/press-release-transmart-informatics-platform-be-used-1m-phelan-mcdermid-syndrome</a></div>
<main aria-label="2014-07 PRESS RELEASE - TranSmart Informatics Platform to be Used in $1M Phelan-McDermid Syndrome Research Project" aria-labelledby="page-title" id="main-content" lang="en" role="main" tabindex="-1">
<div class="layout-content">
<div>
<div class="hidden" data-drupal-messages-fallback=""></div>
<article class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
<h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
<span>2014-07 PRESS RELEASE - TranSmart Informatics Platform to be Used in $1M Phelan-McDermid Syndrome Research Project</span>
</h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
<div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>NEW YORK (GenomeWeb) â The TranSmart Foundation said today that its data-sharing and -analysis platform will be used by the Phelan-McDermid Syndrome Foundation and the Center of Biomedical Informatics at Harvard Medical School as part of a nearly $1 million contract research project.<br/><br/></p><p><a href="https://www.genomeweb.com/informatics/transmart-informatics-platform-be-used-1m-phelan-mcdermid-syndrome-research-proj">https://www.genomeweb.com/informatics/transmart-informatics-platform-be-used-1m-phelan-mcdermid-syndrome-research-proj</a></p></div>

<!-- Source: avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/phenome-wide-association-studies-quantitative-trait-application-tpmt-enzymatic-activity -->
<h1>2014-04 PRESENTATION - Phenome-wide association studies on a quantitative trait: Application to TPMT enzymatic activity | Avillach Lab</h1>
<div class='source-url'><a href='https://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/phenome-wide-association-studies-quantitative-trait-application-tpmt-enzymatic-activity'>avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu/phenome-wide-association-studies-quantitative-trait-application-tpmt-enzymatic-activity</a></div>
<main aria-label="2014-04 PRESENTATION - Phenome-wide association studies on a quantitative trait: Application to TPMT enzymatic activity " aria-labelledby="page-title" id="main-content" lang="en" role="main" tabindex="-1">
<div class="layout-content">
<div>
<div class="hidden" data-drupal-messages-fallback=""></div>
<article class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full" lang="en">
<div class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
<h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
<span>2014-04 PRESENTATION - Phenome-wide association studies on a quantitative trait: Application to TPMT enzymatic activity </span>
</h1>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64">
<div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
<div class="hwp-news-footer hwp-py-24 hwp-pt-0 hwp-container hwp-container-px">
<div class="hwp-attachments" data-component-name="attachments">
<hr class="hwp-text-button-light-secondary hwp-my-32"/>
<span>Attachments</span>
<ul aria-label="Attachments" class="lg:hwp-grid hwp-attachments__items">

<main aria-label="Luke Sikina" aria-labelledby="page-title" id="main-content" lang="en" role="main" tabindex="-1">
<div class="layout-content">
<div>
<div class="hidden" data-drupal-messages-fallback=""></div>

<div class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">

      Luke Sikina
    </h1>
<div class="hwp-page-header__subtitle">
<div class="field field--name-field-hwp-person-prof-title field--type-string field--label-hidden">
<div>Senior Full Stack Software Engineer </div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-pt-32 lg:hwp-pt-64 lg:hwp-flex lg:hwp-gap-24">
<div class="lg:hwp-w-[19.375rem]">
<div class="hwp-person-card" data-component-name="person-card">
<div class="hwp-person-card__image">
