%0 Journal Article
%A Catherine Quantin
%A BÃ©atrice Gouyon
%A Paul Avillach
%A Cyril Ferdynus
%A Paul Sagot
%A Jean-Bernard Gouyon
%B Int J Telemed Appl
%D 2009
%G eng
%P 181842
%R 10.1155/2009/181842
%T Using discharge abstracts to evaluate a regional perinatal network: assessment of the linkage procedure of anonymous data.
%V 2009
%1 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19125196?dopt=Abstract
%X To assess the Burgundy perinatal network (18 obstetrical units; 18 500 births per year), discharge abstracts and additional data were collected for all mothers and newborns. In accordance with French law, data were rendered anonymous before statistical analysis, and were linked to patients using a specific procedure. This procedure allowed data concerning each mother to be linked to those for her newborn(s). This study showed that all mothers and newborns were included in the regional database; the data for all mothers were linked to those for their infant(s) in all cases. Additional data (gestational age) were obtained for 99.9% of newborns.

%0 Journal Article
%A Paul Avillach
%A Michel Joubert
%A Marius Fieschi
%B Health Care Manag Sci
%D 2008
%G eng
%N 2
%P 147-51
%T Improving the quality of the coding of primary diagnosis in standardized discharge summaries.
%V 11
%1 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18581821?dopt=Abstract
%8 06/2008
%X We propose to design and test an information-processing model to participate in appraising the quality and the consistency of the coding, for billing, of Standardized Discharge Summaries (SDSs). We designed a model using both symbolic knowledge extracted from the NLM's UMLS and statistical knowledge. The aim is to retrieve from the ICD-10 terms recorded in a SDS the Principal Diagnosis (PD) at the time of coding. In 90% of cases the PD was retrieved 1st or 2nd in SDS including three ICD-10 codes or more. This model could contribute as part of an automated quality control process in a hospital information system by checking consistency in coded SDSs and improve the income of the hospital.

%0 Journal Article
%A Michel Joubert
%A Stefan Darmoni
%A Paul Avillach
%A Badisse Dahamna
%A Marius Fieschi
%B Stud Health Technol Inform
%D 2008
%G eng
%P 205-10
%T Using knowledge for indexing health web resources in a quality-controlled gateway.
%V 136
%1 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18487732?dopt=Abstract
%X OBJECTIVES: The aim of this study is to provide to indexers MeSH terms to be considered as major ones in a list of terms automatically extracted from a document.MATERIAL AND METHODS: We propose a method combining symbolic knowledge - the UMLS Metathesaurus and Semantic Network - and statistical knowledge drawn from co-occurrences of terms in the CISMeF database (a French-language quality-controlled health gateway) using data mining measures. The method was tested on CISMeF corpus of 293 resources.RESULTS: There was a proportion of 0.37+/-0.26 major terms in the processed records. The method produced lists of terms with a proportion of terms initially pointed out as major of 0.54+/-0.31.DISCUSSION: The method we propose reduces the number of terms, which seem not useful for content description of resources, such as "check tags", but retains the most descriptive ones. Discarding these terms is accounted for by: 1) the removal by using semantic knowledge of associations of concepts bearing no real medical significance, 2) the removal by using statistical knowledge of nonstatistically significant associations of terms.CONCLUSION: This method can assist effectively indexers in their daily work and will be soon applied in the CISMeF system.

%0 Journal Article
%A Catherine Quantin
%A FranÃ§ois-AndrÃ© Allaert
%A Paul Avillach
%A Maniane Fassa
%A BenoÃ®t Riandey
%A Gilles Trouessin
%A Olivier Cohen
%B Int J Telemed Appl
%D 2008
%G eng
%P 678302
%R 10.1155/2008/678302
%T Building application-related patient identifiers: what solution for a European country?
%1 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18401447?dopt=Abstract
%X We propose a method utilizing a derived social security number with the same reliability as the social security number. We show the anonymity techniques classically based on unidirectional hash functions (such as the secure hash algorithm (SHA-2) function that can guarantee the security, quality, and reliability of information if these techniques are applied to the Social Security Number). Hashing produces a strictly anonymous code that is always the same for a given individual, and thus enables patient data to be linked. Different solutions are developed and proposed in this article. Hashing the social security number will make it possible to link the information in the personal medical file to other national health information sources with the aim of completing or validating the personal medical record or conducting epidemiological and clinical research. This data linkage would meet the anonymous data requirements of the European directive on data protection.

%0 Journal Article
%A Paul Avillach
%A Michel Joubert
%A Marius Fieschi
%B AMIA Annu Symp Proc
%D 2007
%G eng
%P 31-5
%T A model for indexing medical documents combining statistical and symbolic knowledge.
%1 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18693792?dopt=Abstract
%X OBJECTIVES: To develop and evaluate an information processing method based on terminologies, in order to index medical documents in any given documentary context.METHODS: We designed a model using both symbolic general knowledge extracted from the Unified Medical Language System (UMLS) and statistical knowledge extracted from a domain of application. Using statistical knowledge allowed us to contextualize the general knowledge for every particular situation. For each document studied, the extracted terms are ranked to highlight the most significant ones. The model was tested on a set of 17,079 French standardized discharge summaries (SDSs).RESULTS: The most important ICD-10 term of each SDS was ranked 1st or 2nd by the method in nearly 90% of the cases.CONCLUSIONS: The use of several terminologies leads to more precise indexing. The improvement achieved in the models implementation performances as a result of using semantic relationships is encouraging.

%0 Journal Article
%A Quantin
%A Allaert
%A Fassa
%A Avillach
%A Fieschi
%A Cohen
%B Conf Proc IEEE Eng Med Biol Soc
%D 2007
%G eng
%P 6161
%R 10.1109/IEMBS.2007.4353760
%T Interoperability issues regarding patient identification in Europe.
%V 2007
%1 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18003426?dopt=Abstract

%0 Journal Article
%A Catherine Quantin
%A FranÃ§ois-AndrÃ© Allaert
%A Paul Avillach
%A BenoÃ®t Riandey
%A Marius Fieschi
%A Maniane Fassa
%A Olivier Cohen
%B Stud Health Technol Inform
%D 2007
%G eng
%N Pt 1
%P 503-7
%T Proposal of a French health identification number interoperable at the European level.
%V 129
%1 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17911768?dopt=Abstract
%X The French ministry of Health is setting up the Personal Medical Record (PMR). This innovative tool has long been expected by French Health Authorities, Associations of Patients, other Health's associations, those defending Individual Liberties and the French National Data Protection Authority. The PMR will lead to improvements in many areas such as Diagnosis (Research and monitoring) Healthcare (Management of emergencies, urgent situations, Temporal health monitoring and evaluation), Therapy (Cohorts of patients for Clinical trials and epidemiological studies). The PMR will foster safe healthcare management, clinical research and epidemiological studies. Nevertheless, it raises many important questions regarding duplicates and the quality, precision and coherence of the linkage with other health data coming from different sources. The currently planned identifying process raises many questions with regard to its ability to deal with potential duplicates and to perform data linkage with other health data sources. Through this article, using the electronic health records, we develop and propose an identification process to improve the French PMR. Our proposed unique patient identifier will guarantee the security, confidentiality and privacy of the personal data, and will prove to be particularly useful for health planning, health policies and research as well as clinical and epidemiological studies. Finally, it will certainly be interoperable with other European health information systems. We propose here an alternative identification procedure that would allow France to broaden the scope of its PMR project by making it possible to contribute to public health research and policy while increasing interoperability with European health information systems and preserving the confidentiality of the data.

%0 Journal Article
%A Catherine Quantin
%A FranÃ§ois AndrÃ© Allaert
%A Maniane Fassa
%A BenoÃ®t Riandey
%A Paul Avillach
%A Olivier Cohen
%B Stud Health Technol Inform
%D 2007
%G eng
%P 246-55
%T How to manage secure direct access of European patients to their computerized medical record and personal medical record.
%V 127
%1 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17901616?dopt=Abstract
%X The multiplication of the requests of the patients for a direct access to their Medical Record (MR), the development of Personal Medical Record (PMR) supervised by the patients themselves, the increasing development of the patients' electronic medical records (EMRs) and the world wide internet utilization will lead to envisage an access by using technical automatic and scientific way. It will require the addition of different conditions: a unique patient identifier which could base on a familial component in order to get access to the right record anywhere in Europe, very strict identity checks using cryptographic techniques such as those for the electronic signature, which will ensure the authentication of the requests sender and the integrity of the file but also the protection of the confidentiality and the access follow up. The electronic medical record must also be electronically signed by the practitioner in order to get evidence that he has given his agreement and taken the liability for that. This electronic signature also avoids any kind of post-transmission falsification. This will become extremely important, especially in France where patients will have the possibility to mask information that, they do not want to appear in their personal medical record. Currently, the idea of every citizen having electronic signatures available appears positively Utopian. But this is yet the case in eGovernment, eHealth and eShopping, world-wide. The same was thought about smart cards before they became generally available and useful when banks issued them.

  <main lang="en" id="main-content" role="main" aria-label="Patient-Centered Information Commons" aria-labelledby="page-title" tabindex="-1">
    <div class="layout-content">
        <div>
    <div data-drupal-messages-fallback class="hidden"></div>

<article lang="en" class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full">
  <div  class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
  <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
    
    <h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
      <span>Patient-Centered Information Commons</span>

    </h1>
    
     </div>
</div>

        <div
      class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64 ">
            <div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
                  
            <div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>	NIH/BD2K U54 HG007963</p><p>	Co-Investigator (PI: Isaac Kohane)</p><p>	We propose to create a massively scalable toolkit to enable large, multi-center Patient-centered Informatic Commons (PIC) at loval, regional, and national scale, where the focus is the alignment of all available biomedical data per individual. Such a Commons is a prerequisite for conducting the large-N, Big Data, longitudinal studies essential for understanding causation in the Precision Medicine framework while simultaneously addressing key complexities of Patient Centric Outcome Research studies required under ACA (Affordable Care Act).</p></div>
      
        
        
                  

<div class="hwp-news-footer hwp-py-24 hwp-pt-0 hwp-container hwp-container-px">
                
            
  <div class="page-tags">
    
      <span class="hwp-mb-16 hwp-block">See also:</span>
        <ul class="hwp-news-footer__tags hwp-flex hwp-flex-wrap hwp-gap-16 hwp-mb-24">
                        <li class="max-sm:hwp-w-full">
            <a href="/research/past" class="hwp-button-tag hwp-button-tag--dark">
              Past
            </a>
          </li>
                  </ul>
  </div>

        
  </div>
              </div>
    </div>
  
  </article>

  </div>

    </div>
    
      </main>

  <main lang="en" id="main-content" role="main" aria-label="PCORI CDRN: Scalable Collaborative Infrastructure for a Learning Healthcare System (SCILHS) - Phase II" aria-labelledby="page-title" tabindex="-1">
    <div class="layout-content">
        <div>
    <div data-drupal-messages-fallback class="hidden"></div>

<article lang="en" class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full">
  <div  class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
  <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
    
    <h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
      <span>PCORI CDRN: Scalable Collaborative Infrastructure for a Learning Healthcare System (SCILHS) - Phase II</span>

    </h1>
    
     </div>
</div>

        <div
      class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64 ">
            <div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
                  
            <div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>PCORI - CDRN</p><p>Co-Investigator</p><p>PI: Kenneth Mandl</p><p>Leveraging an informatics infrastructure that our investigators have developed over the past 15 years, the Department of Biomedical Informatics (DBMI) at Harvard Medical School will work across 10 healthcare centers throughout the U.S. to develop the Scalable Collaborative Infrastructure for a Learning Health System (SCILHS, pronounced âskillsâ). An open-source platform, the system will cover more than 8 million patients and enable clinician and patient participation in research</p><p>&nbsp;</p></div>
      
        
        
                  

<div class="hwp-news-footer hwp-py-24 hwp-pt-0 hwp-container hwp-container-px">
                
            
  <div class="page-tags">
    
      <span class="hwp-mb-16 hwp-block">See also:</span>
        <ul class="hwp-news-footer__tags hwp-flex hwp-flex-wrap hwp-gap-16 hwp-mb-24">
                        <li class="max-sm:hwp-w-full">
            <a href="/research/past" class="hwp-button-tag hwp-button-tag--dark">
              Past
            </a>
          </li>
                  </ul>
  </div>

        
  </div>
              </div>
    </div>
  
  </article>

  </div>

    </div>
    
      </main>

  <main lang="en" id="main-content" role="main" aria-label="PCORI PPRN - Phelan McDermid Syndrome Data Network (PMS_DN) Phase II" aria-labelledby="page-title" tabindex="-1">
    <div class="layout-content">
        <div>
    <div data-drupal-messages-fallback class="hidden"></div>

<article lang="en" class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full">
  <div  class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
  <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
    
    <h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
      <span>PCORI PPRN - Phelan McDermid Syndrome Data Network (PMS_DN) Phase II</span>

    </h1>
    
     </div>
</div>

        <div
      class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64 ">
            <div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
                  
            <div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>Co-PI ($1.2M) Total $1.6M (PI: Megan O'Boyle from <a href="http://22q13.org/j15/">PMSF</a>)</p><p><a href="http://www.pcori.org/research-results/2013/phelan-mcdermid-syndrome-data-network">Phelan McDermid Syndrome Data Network (PMS_DN): A PCORI Patient Powered Research Network</a></p><p>The PMS_DN mission is to advance knowledge, care, and treatment of Phelan-McDermid Syndrome (PMS), and related conditions by integrating diverse, complex datasets from multiple sources into a richly populated, high quality, and accessible centralized database to facilitate patient-centered research. The network promotes a culture of transparency and authentic engagement and leadership of families in network vision, governance, and generation of research priorities. The organizations participating in the PMS_DN include: The Phelan McDermid Syndrome Foundation (PMSF), the Department of Biomedical Informatics at Harvard Medical School (HMS), and Boston Children's Hospital</p></div>
      
        
        
                  

<div class="hwp-news-footer hwp-py-24 hwp-pt-0 hwp-container hwp-container-px">
                
            
  <div class="page-tags">
    
      <span class="hwp-mb-16 hwp-block">See also:</span>
        <ul class="hwp-news-footer__tags hwp-flex hwp-flex-wrap hwp-gap-16 hwp-mb-24">
                        <li class="max-sm:hwp-w-full">
            <a href="/research/past" class="hwp-button-tag hwp-button-tag--dark">
              Past
            </a>
          </li>
                  </ul>
  </div>

        
  </div>
              </div>
    </div>
  
  </article>

  </div>

    </div>
    
      </main>

  <main lang="en" id="main-content" role="main" aria-label="PCORI PPRN - Phelan-McDermid Syndrome Data Network" aria-labelledby="page-title" tabindex="-1">
    <div class="layout-content">
        <div>
    <div data-drupal-messages-fallback class="hidden"></div>

<article lang="en" class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full">
  <div  class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
  <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
    
    <h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
      <span>PCORI PPRN - Phelan-McDermid Syndrome Data Network</span>

    </h1>
    
     </div>
</div>

        <div
      class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64 ">
            <div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
                  
            <div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>Co-PI ($624K)&nbsp; Total $950K &nbsp; (PI &nbsp;Megan O'Boyle from&nbsp;<a href="http://22q13.org/j15/">PMSF</a> )<br>PCORI - PPRN&nbsp;<a href="http://www.pcori.org/research-results/2013/phelan-mcdermid-syndrome-data-network">http://www.pcori.org/research-results/2013/phelan-mcdermid-syndrome-data-network</a></p><p><span>&nbsp;The PMS_DN mission is to advance knowledge, care, and treatment of Phelan-McDermid Syndrome (PMS) and related conditions by integrating diverse, complex data sources into a richly populated, high quality, and accessible centralized database to facilitate patient-centered research. The network promotes a culture of transparency and authentic engagement and leadership of families in network vision, governance, and generation of research priorities. The organizations participating in the PMS_DN include: The Phelan-McDermid Syndrome Foundation, the Harvard Medical School (HMS) Department of Biomedical Informatics, and Boston Childrenâs Hospital.</span><br>&nbsp;</p><p><span>PMS, a rare genetic condition caused by errors on the end of chromosome 22 (22q13), is associated with autism/autism spectrum disorders, intellectual disabilities, sleep disorders, and seizures. There is no treatment for PMS. There are ~1,100 </span><em><span>diagnosed cases</span></em><span> worldwide, with at least 520 cases confirmed in the US. However, a conservative estimate, regardless if known/diagnosed, is 8,898 US cases. Since PMS_DNâs launch in July 2014, 281 families have consented to participate in the network and PCORnet studies (~50% of known US diagnosed cases). The PMS_DNâs enrollment target for Phase II is 400 US cases (~75% of known US diagnosed cases). PCORnet offers a vital opportunity to advance knowledge and care for PMS, capitalizing on the consortium to enroll families in observational studies and pragmatic clinical trials, while identifying undiagnosed individuals and connecting families to needed services. The PMS_DN brings unique assets to PCORnet: an established data portal for collecting patient-reported outcomes (PROs), the PMS International Registry (PMSIR), and i2b2/tranSMART, a platform that allows researchers to analyze complex data types harmonized to the PCORnet Common Data Model (CDM) v2 and enables integration of PROs with validated knowledge extracted from EHR clinical notes through Natural Language Processing (NLP).</span></p><p><span>The PMS_DN integrates PROs with data from the application of NLP to EHR clinical notes submitted by families. The technical platform to achieve this integration and harmonize data domains with the current version of the PCORnet CDM is i2b2/tranSMART. The PMS_DN completed a mapping file for PRO data that has been validated with real patient data and production of an audit trail of the clinical data integration pipeline in tranSMART. An advantage of i2b2/tranSMART is that an investigator can quickly validate outcomes of interest from the output of the NLP with the i2b2/tranSMART interface, viewing all anonymized sentences from which the concept was generated. The network uses cTAKES including a new temporal module that extracts time and event concepts from clinical notes, enabling a complete longitudinal view of a patient. The PMS_DN maps to several ontologies/terminologies: SNOMED CT, ICD9, ICD10, Human Phenotype Ontology, Gene Ontology, and MeSH.</span></p><div class="hwp-media hwp-media--full-width">
  
  
            <div class="field field--name-field-media-image field--type-image field--label-hidden">  <img loading="lazy" src="/sites/g/files/omnuum4001/files/avillach_lab/files/capture_decran_2014-05-06_21.04.15_0.png" width="1000" height="664" alt="capture_decran_2014-05-06_21.04.15.png">

</div>
      
</div>
</div>
      
        
        
                  

<div class="hwp-news-footer hwp-py-24 hwp-pt-0 hwp-container hwp-container-px">

<div  lang="en" class="page-content-top">
  <div  class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
  <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
    
    <h1 class="text-large" >
      Carlos SÃ¡ez
    </h1>
    
       <div class="hwp-page-header__subtitle">
      
      <div class="field field--name-field-hwp-person-prof-title field--type-string field--label-hidden">
              <div>Visiting Research Fellow at Harvard Medical School</div>
              <div>Postdoctoral Researcher at Universitat PolitÃ¨cnica de ValÃ¨ncia, Spain</div>
          </div>
  
    </div>
      </div>
</div>
  <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-pt-32 lg:hwp-pt-64 lg:hwp-flex lg:hwp-gap-24">
          <div class="lg:hwp-w-[19.375rem]">
            <div  class="hwp-person-card" data-component-name="person-card">
      <div class="hwp-person-card__image ">
                      
            <div class="field field--name-field-hwp-person-headshot field--type-entity-reference field--label-hidden"><div class="hwp-media hwp-media--4-5-small-no-caption">
  
  
            <div class="field field--name-field-media-image field--type-image field--label-hidden">    <picture>
                  <source srcset="/sites/g/files/omnuum4001/files/styles/hwp_4_5__480x600/public/avillach_lab/files/img_0275_s2.jpg?itok=kYAk_ZrW 1x, /sites/g/files/omnuum4001/files/styles/hwp_4_5__960x1200/public/avillach_lab/files/img_0275_s2.jpg?itok=xysADbTM 2x" media="all and (min-width: 0)" type="image/jpeg" width="480" height="600"/>
                  <img loading="lazy" width="480" height="600" src="/sites/g/files/omnuum4001/files/styles/hwp_4_5__480x600/public/avillach_lab/files/img_0275_s2.jpg?itok=kYAk_ZrW" alt="Carlos SÃ¡ez" />

  </picture>

</div>
      
</div>
</div>
      
                </div>
  
    <div class="hwp-person-card__information hwp-bg-light-base hwp-flex-1">        <div class="hwp-flex hwp-gap-8 hwp-items-center">
          <span class="material-icon" aria-hidden="true">email</span>
          <a href="mailto:carlos_saez@hms.harvard.edu" class="hwp-break-all">carlos_saez@hms.harvard.edu</a>
        </div>
            <div class="hwp-mb-24 hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-gap-20">
                  <div class="hwp-flex hwp-gap-8 hwp-items-center">
            <span class="material-icon" aria-hidden="true">laptop_windows</span>
            <a href="https://scholar.google.es/citations?user=OkBVoyoAAAAJ&amp;sortby=pubdate">Publications in Google Scholar</a>
          </div>
               </div>
      </div>
</div>
        </div>
        <div
      class="hwp-flex-1 lg:hwp-px-32"
    >
          <div class="hwp-person-text-block">
      
            <div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>	PhD in Technologies for Health and Well-Being,&nbsp;MsC in Artificial Intelligence, Pattern Recognition and Digital Imaging. He is researcher at the Biomedical Data Science Lab (ITACA Institute) of the Universitat PolitÃ¨cnica de ValÃ¨ncia (UPV) since 2006.&nbsp;His current research focuses on&nbsp;the characterization of biomedical data variability and in the developemnt of novel biomedical data quality assessment methods. He has participated&nbsp;in several European, National and private projects, has been PI of&nbsp;two&nbsp;National projects.&nbsp;Two of his publications were selected as best of published worldwide by the International Medical Informatics Association in the fields of Secondary Use of Patient Data (2016) and Health Information Systems (2013). At UPV he collaborates teaching Data Quality and Interoperability, Health Information Systems and Bioinformatics.</p><p>	&nbsp;</p></div>
      
    </div>
      </div>
  </div>

<div  lang="en" class="page-content-top">
  <div  class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
  <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
    
    <h1 class="text-large" >
      Paul Avillach, MD, PhD
    </h1>
    
       <div class="hwp-page-header__subtitle">
      
      <div class="field field--name-field-hwp-person-prof-title field--type-string field--label-hidden">
              <div>Assistant Professor at Harvard Medical School</div>
          </div>
  
    </div>
      </div>
</div>
  <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-pt-32 lg:hwp-pt-64 lg:hwp-flex lg:hwp-gap-24">
          <div class="lg:hwp-w-[19.375rem]">
            <div  class="hwp-person-card" data-component-name="person-card">
      <div class="hwp-person-card__image ">
                      
            <div class="field field--name-field-hwp-person-headshot field--type-entity-reference field--label-hidden"><div class="hwp-media hwp-media--4-5-small-no-caption">
  
  
            <div class="field field--name-field-media-image field--type-image field--label-hidden">    <picture>
                  <source srcset="/sites/g/files/omnuum4001/files/styles/hwp_4_5__480x600/public/avillach_lab/files/paul_avillach_h.jpg?itok=DT9lYtlP 1x, /sites/g/files/omnuum4001/files/styles/hwp_4_5__960x1200/public/avillach_lab/files/paul_avillach_h.jpg?itok=ggQZ85Au 2x" media="all and (min-width: 0)" type="image/jpeg" width="480" height="600"/>
                  <img loading="lazy" width="480" height="600" src="/sites/g/files/omnuum4001/files/styles/hwp_4_5__480x600/public/avillach_lab/files/paul_avillach_h.jpg?itok=DT9lYtlP" alt="Dr. Paul Avillach" />

  </picture>

</div>
      
</div>
</div>
      
                </div>
  
    <div class="hwp-person-card__information hwp-bg-light-base hwp-flex-1">        <div class="hwp-flex hwp-gap-8 hwp-items-center">
          <span class="material-icon" aria-hidden="true">email</span>
          <a href="mailto:paul_avillach@hms.harvard.edu" class="hwp-break-all">paul_avillach@hms.harvard.edu</a>
        </div>
      </div>
</div>
        </div>
        <div
      class="hwp-flex-1 lg:hwp-px-32"
    >
          <div class="hwp-person-text-block">
      
            <div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>Dr. Avillach is Assistant Professor in Pediatrics &amp; Biomedical Informatics, Harvard Medical School and Boston Childrenâs Hospital. He received his MD in Public Health from University of Bordeaux, France and PhD in Biomedical Informatics from University of Marseilles, France. His work focuses on translational bioinformatics, combining clinical and genomic data across different scales and resolutions to address essential biomedical questions.</p><p><a href="/"><strong>http://avillach-lab.hms.harvard.edu</strong></a><strong>&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong><br>Department of Biomedical Informatics | Harvard Medical School &nbsp;<a href="https://dbmi.hms.harvard.edu/">https://dbmi.hms.harvard.edu</a>&nbsp;&nbsp;<br>Childrenâs Hospital Informatics Program &nbsp;| &nbsp;Boston Childrenâs Hospital &nbsp;<a href="http://chip.org/">http://chip.org</a>&nbsp;&nbsp;</p></div>
      
    </div>
      </div>
  </div>
</div>

  <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-pt-32 md:hwp-pt-64">

</div>

e=BOOMR.subscribe;e("before_beacon",r.av,null,null),e("onbeacon",r.rv,null,null),r.i=!0}return this},is_complete:function(){return!0}}}}()}(window);</script></head>

    <h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
      <span>People</span>

    </h1>
    
     </div>
</div>

              <div class="paragraphs-item__first paragraphs-item">




<div  class="hwp-hero hwp-hero--split-horizontal hwp-hero--medium hwp-hero--static"  data-component-name="hwp-hero">
  <div class="hwp-hero__slides js-hwp-hero-slider-trigger">

            <h2 class="hwp-hero__title hwp-order-2 h1"
    id="">
    Avillach Lab Members
  </h2>
          <div class="hwp-hero__description hwp-order-3 hwp-text-block">
      
            <div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>Members of the Avillach Lab, including the current team and alumni.&nbsp;</p></div>
      
    </div>
    <div class="hwp-hero__buttons hwp-order-4">
        
    </div>
  </div>
<div class="hwp-hero__media hwp-bg-light-core">
      <div class="hwp-media hwp-media--28-10-medium-hero">

  <div class="page-card__text hwp-order-1">

        <div class="page-card__image page-card__image--4-5">
              <div class="page-card__thumb">
          <div class="hwp-media hwp-media--4-5-person-list-no-caption">

  <main lang="en" id="main-content" role="main" aria-label="Phelan-McDermid Syndrome Data Network (PMS_DN) - Phase I" aria-labelledby="page-title" tabindex="-1">

<article lang="en" class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full">
  <div  class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
  <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
    
    <h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
      <span>Phelan-McDermid Syndrome Data Network (PMS_DN) - Phase I</span>

    </h1>
    
     </div>
</div>

        <div
      class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64 ">
            <div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
                  
            <div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>	PCORI - PPRN</p><p>	Co-PI ($624K) Total $950K (PI: Megan O'Boyle)</p><p>	To collect all available patient data from Phelan-McDermid Syndrome (PMS) patients to make meaningful, well-annotated clinical data available to researchers and to share insights with members of the PCORI network.</p><p>	TranSMART platform based on i2b2 is being used to integrate Patient Reported Outcomes and Knowledge extracted from Clinical Notes using cTAKES</p></div>
      
        
        
                  

<div class="hwp-news-footer hwp-py-24 hwp-pt-0 hwp-container hwp-container-px">
                
            
  <div class="page-tags">
    
      <span class="hwp-mb-16 hwp-block">See also:</span>
        <ul class="hwp-news-footer__tags hwp-flex hwp-flex-wrap hwp-gap-16 hwp-mb-24">
                        <li class="max-sm:hwp-w-full">
            <a href="/research/past" class="hwp-button-tag hwp-button-tag--dark">
              Past
            </a>
          </li>
                  </ul>
  </div>

        
  </div>
              </div>
    </div>
  
  </article>

  </div>

    </div>
    
      </main>

  <main lang="en" id="main-content" role="main" aria-label="PIC-SURE" aria-labelledby="page-title" tabindex="-1">
    <div class="layout-content">
        <div>
    <div data-drupal-messages-fallback class="hidden"></div>

<article lang="en" class="node node--type-hwp-page node--view-mode-full">
  <div  class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
  <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
    
    <h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
      <span>PIC-SURE</span>

    </h1>
    
     </div>
</div>

        <div
      class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64 ">
            <div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
                  
            <div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><h2>Introduction to PIC-SURE</h2><p dir="ltr"><span>The Patient-centered Information Commons: Standard Unification of Research Elements (PIC-SURE) platform integrates different layers of clinical and genomic data from diverse data sources, providing a multifaceted approach to biomedical research.&nbsp;</span></p><p dir="ltr"><span>The PIC-SURE platform was built on </span><a href="https://www.i2b2.org/"><span>Informatics for Integrating Biology &amp; the Bedside (i2b2)</span></a><span>, a data model created for electronic health record data. PIC-SURE is developed with an open-source Apache 2.0 license and deployed in Federal Information Security Modernization Act (FISMA) Moderate ATO and HI-TRUST environments.</span></p><p dir="ltr">&nbsp;</p><h2><span>Features of PIC-SURE</span></h2><h3><span>User Interface and Application Programming Interface</span></h3><p><span>The PIC-SURE platform provides both an intuitive graphical user interface (UI) and an application programming interface (API) to meet different use cases and levels of experience with data manipulation. The PIC-SURE UI allows for an investigator to search for variables of interest and to conduct feasibility queries. In this way, cohorts are built in real-time and results can be retrieved for analysis.&nbsp;</span></p><h3><span>Query Builder</span></h3><p><span>The Query Builder in the PIC-SURE UI allows users to interactively build queries and returns the counts of participants that meet the criteria. This tool functions similarly to a search engine, providing the ability to search a term of interest and returning variables that contain the search term. After determining a variable of interest, users can refine their query to filter participants with certain values and build a cohort. Both single and multiple criteria queries are supported.</span></p><h3><span>GitHub</span></h3><p dir="ltr"><span>PIC-SURE is developed under an Apache 2.0 license; all code is open source and accessible on the </span><a href="https://github.com/hms-dbmi/pic-sure-all-in-one"><span>PIC-SURE All-in-one GitHub repository</span></a><span>. &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></p><p dir="ltr"><span>For users interested in the PIC-SURE API, several Jupyter notebooks (R and Python) and R Markdown files contain coding examples for key PIC-SURE use cases. These examples provide a starting point for users to get started with their own analyses and are publicly available on the </span><a href="https://github.com/hms-dbmi/Access-to-Data-using-PIC-SURE-API"><span>Access to Data Using PIC-SURE API GitHub Repository</span></a><span>. &nbsp;</span></p><p dir="ltr">&nbsp;</p><h2><span>Training Materials</span></h2><h3><span>Documentation&nbsp;</span></h3><p><span>Written documentation for PIC-SURE can be found on the </span><a href="https://pic-sure.gitbook.io/pic-sure"><span>PIC-SURE Gitbook documentation</span></a><span>. &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></p><h3><span>Videos&nbsp;</span></h3><p>The <a href="https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCIfahDUjW4A4B1KyIek4YJA">PIC-SURE YouTube channel</a> has video demonstrations of PIC-SURE features such as searching, filtering, and building cohorts. Researchers can find videos specific to certain PIC-SURE environments by <a href="https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCIfahDUjW4A4B1KyIek4YJA/playlists">viewing the playlists</a>.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><h2>PIC-SURE Instances</h2><h3>Demo PIC-SURE</h3><p>The demonstration site of PIC-SURE allows users to access the <a href="https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/nhanes/index.html">National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) dataset</a>. You can submit a request to access the site by emailing <a href="mailto:avillach_lab_developers@googlegroups.com">avillach_lab_developers@googlegroups.com</a>.&nbsp;</p><h3>NHLBI BioData CatalystÂ®</h3><p>The National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute BioData CatalystÂ® (BDC) is a cloud-based ecosystem that offers researchers data, analytic tools, applications, and workflows in secure workspaces.&nbsp;</p><p><a href="https://picsure.biodatacatalyst.nhlbi.nih.gov/">BDC Powered by PIC-SURE</a> is available to search hosted heart, lung, blood, and sleep data publicly.&nbsp;</p><h3>Genomic Information Commons&nbsp;</h3><p>The Genomic Information Commons (GIC) is a continuously updating, queryable, federated genomic data commons. <span>Inspired by a common vision of accelerated genomic research discovery, collaboration, and improved clinical outcomes, leaders at Boston Childrenâs Hospital (BCH), Harvard Medical School, Cincinnati Childrenâs Hospital Medical Center (CCHMC), the Childrenâs Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP), St. Louis Childrenâs Hospital (SLCH)/Washington University at St. Louis (WUSTL), and the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center (UPMC) have come together to create the GIC.</span></p><p><span>The GIC is available to those in the GIC consortium. You can learn more at the </span><a href="https://www.genomicinformationcommons.org/"><span>GIC website</span></a><span>.&nbsp;</span></p><h3>AIM-AHEAD</h3><p>The National Institute of Health's AIM-AHEAD program has established mutually beneficial, coordinated, and trusted partnerships to enhance the participation and representation of researchers and communities currently under-resourced in the development of artificial intelligence and machine learning models and to improve the capabilities of this emerging technology, beginning with electronic health records (EHR) and extending to other data sets to address health inconsistencies.&nbsp;</p><p>To learn more, please refer to the <a href="https://www.aim-ahead.net/">AIM-AHEAD website</a>.&nbsp;</p></div>
      
        
        
              </div>
    </div>
  
  </article>

  </div>

    </div>
    
      </main>

  <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
    
    <h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
      <span>2015-05 PRESENTATION - INSAR - Creating a patient centric information commons for autism research</span>

    </h1>
    
     </div>
</div>

        <div
      class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64 ">
            <div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
                  
            <div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>Megan OâBoyle and Geraldine Bliss - patients advocates from the&nbsp;<a href="http://22q13.org">Phelan McDermid Syndrome fondation</a> - with &nbsp;Isaac Kohane and Paul Avillach from CBMI are presenting a Special Interest Group on&nbsp;<strong>Creating a patient centric information commons for autism research</strong>&nbsp;at the International Society for Autism Research (INSAR) annual meeting May 13-16 &nbsp;Salt Lake City, Utah, USA</p><p><a href="http://www.autism-insar.org/imfar-annual-meeting/imfar-2015">http://www.autism-insar.org/imfar-annual-meeting/imfar-2015</a></p></div>
      
        
        
              </div>
    </div>

  <div  class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
  <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
    
    <h1 class="text-large" id="page-title">
      <span>2014-07 PRESS RELEASE - TranSmart Informatics Platform to be Used in $1M Phelan-McDermid Syndrome Research Project</span>

    </h1>
    
     </div>
</div>

        <div
      class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-w-full hwp-py-32 lg:hwp-py-64 ">
            <div class="hwp-flex hwp-flex-col hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden">
                  
            <div class="hwp-text-block field field--name-field-hwp-body field--type-text-long field--label-hidden"><p>NEW YORK (GenomeWeb) â The TranSmart Foundation said today that its data-sharing and -analysis platform will be used by the Phelan-McDermid Syndrome Foundation and the Center of Biomedical Informatics at Harvard Medical School as part of a nearly $1 million contract research project.<br><br></p><p><a href="https://www.genomeweb.com/informatics/transmart-informatics-platform-be-used-1m-phelan-mcdermid-syndrome-research-proj">https://www.genomeweb.com/informatics/transmart-informatics-platform-be-used-1m-phelan-mcdermid-syndrome-research-proj</a></p></div>
      
        
        
              </div>
    </div>
  
  </article>

  </div>

  <div  lang="en" class="hwp-page-title bibcite-reference">
  <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
    
    <h1 class="text-large" >
      Characterization of long COVID temporal sub-phenotypes by distributed representation learning from electronic health record data: a cohort study.
    </h1>
    
     </div>
</div>

  <div class="md:hwp-pt-64">
    <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px max-lg:hwp-px-0">
      <div  class="publication-info" data-component-name="publication-info">
  <div class="publication-info__image">
          
      </div>
  <div class="publication-info__text">
    <h4 class="h4 hwp-mb-8">Publication information:</h4>
    <div class="publication-info__body">
      <div class="bibcite-citation">
      <div class="csl-bib-body"><div class="csl-entry"><div class="csl-left-margin">Dagliati A, Strasser ZH, Abad ZSH, Klann JG, Wagholikar KB, Mesa R, Visweswaran S, Morris M, Luo Y, Henderson DW, Samayamuthu MJ, Tan BWQ, Verdy G, Omenn GS, Xia Z, Bellazzi R, EHR C for CC of C 19 by, Murphy SN, Holmes JH, Estiri H, EHR C for CC of C 19 by. Characterization of long COVID temporal sub-phenotypes by distributed representation learning from electronic health record data: a cohort study.</div><div class="csl-right-inline">EClinicalMedicine. 2023;64:102210. PMID: 37745021</div></div></div>
  </div>

    </div>
    <ul class="publication-info__actions">
              <li>
          <div class="button-dropdown" data-component-name="button-dropdown">

   class="hwp-text-link hwp-text-link--icon-left"
    id="publication_citation_download">
  <span class="material-icon" aria-hidden="true">download_for_offline</span>
<span class="hwp-text-link__text">Download citation</span>
</button>

  
  <ul class="button-dropdown__items" role="menu" aria-labelledby="publication_citation_download">
          <li role="menuitem">
        <a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773876&amp;format=bibtex">BibTeX</a>
      </li>
          <li role="menuitem">
        <a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773876&amp;format=endnote8">EndNote X3 XML</a>
      </li>
          <li role="menuitem">
        <a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773876&amp;format=endnote7">EndNote 7 XML</a>
      </li>
          <li role="menuitem">
        <a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773876&amp;format=tagged">Endnote tagged</a>
      </li>
          <li role="menuitem">
        <a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773876&amp;format=marc">Marc</a>
      </li>
          <li role="menuitem">
        <a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773876&amp;format=pubmed_id">PubMedId</a>
      </li>
          <li role="menuitem">
        <a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773876&amp;format=ris">RIS</a>
      </li>
      </ul>
</div>
        </li>
                </ul>
  </div>
</div>
    </div>
  </div>

      <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-pt-32 hwp-pb-64 md:hwp-py-64">
      <div  class="hwp-citations-group">
      <h3 class="h3 hwp-mb-24">Abstract</h3>
  
  <div class="hwp-citations-group__inner">
                  


<div  class="hwp-citation hwp-citation--text-trim hwp-bg-light-base js-hwp-citation" data-component-name="citation">
  <div class="hwp-citation__text">
    <div class="hwp-text-block__default-text">
      <p><b>BACKGROUND: </b>Characterizing Post-Acute Sequelae of COVID (SARS-CoV-2 Infection), or  has been challenging due to the multitude of sub-phenotypes, temporal attributes, and definitions. Scalable characterization of PASC sub-phenotypes can enhance screening capacities, disease management, and treatment planning.</p><p><b>METHODS: </b>We conducted a retrospective multi-centre observational cohort study, leveraging longitudinal electronic health record (EHR) data of 30,422 patients from three healthcare systems in the Consortium for the Clinical Characterization of COVID-19 by EHR (4CE). From the total cohort, we applied a deductive approach on 12,424 individuals with follow-up data and developed a distributed representation learning process for providing augmented definitions for PASC sub-phenotypes.</p><p><b>FINDINGS: </b>Our framework characterized seven PASC sub-phenotypes. We estimated that on average 15.7% of the hospitalized COVID-19 patients were likely to suffer from at least one PASC symptom and almost 5.98%, on average, had multiple symptoms. Joint pain and dyspnea had the highest prevalence, with an average prevalence of 5.45% and 4.53%, respectively.</p><p><b>INTERPRETATION: </b>We provided a scalable framework to every participating healthcare system for estimating PASC sub-phenotypes prevalence and temporal attributes, thus developing a unified model that characterizes augmented sub-phenotypes across the different systems.</p><p><b>FUNDING: </b>Authors are supported by National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, National Institute on Aging, National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences, National Medical Research Council, National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke, European Union, National Institutes of Health, National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences.</p>
    </div>

    <div class="hwp-text-block">
      <p><b>BACKGROUND: </b>Characterizing Post-Acute Sequelae of COVID (SARS-CoV-2 Infection), or  has been challenging due to the multitude of sub-phenotypes, temporal attributes, and definitions. Scalable characterization of PASC sub-phenotypes can enhance screening capacities, disease management, and treatment planning.</p><p><b>METHODS: </b>We conducted a retrospective multi-centre observational cohort study, leveraging longitudinal electronic health record (EHR) data of 30,422 patients from three healthcare systems in the Consortium for the Clinical Characterization of COVID-19 by EHR (4CE). From the total cohort, we applied a deductive approach on 12,424 individuals with follow-up data and developed a distributed representation learning process for providing augmented definitions for PASC sub-phenotypes.</p><p><b>FINDINGS: </b>Our framework characterized seven PASC sub-phenotypes. We estimated that on average 15.7% of the hospitalized COVID-19 patients were likely to suffer from at least one PASC symptom and almost 5.98%, on average, had multiple symptoms. Joint pain and dyspnea had the highest prevalence, with an average prevalence of 5.45% and 4.53%, respectively.</p><p><b>INTERPRETATION: </b>We provided a scalable framework to every participating healthcare system for estimating PASC sub-phenotypes prevalence and temporal attributes, thus developing a unified model that characterizes augmented sub-phenotypes across the different systems.</p><p><b>FUNDING: </b>Authors are supported by National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, National Institute on Aging, National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences, National Medical Research Council, National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke, European Union, National Institutes of Health, National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences.</p>
    </div>
  </div>

      <ul class="hwp-citation__ctas">
              <li class="expand-button-wrap">
          <button
            class="hwp-text-link hwp-text-link--icon-left hwp-citation__full-body-expand js-hwp-citation__full-body-expand"
            aria-expanded="false"

          >

  <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
    
    <h1 class="text-large" >
      Clinical phenotypes and outcomes in children with multisystem inflammatory syndrome across SARS-CoV-2 variant eras: a multinational study from the 4CE consortium.
    </h1>
    
     </div>
</div>

  <div class="md:hwp-pt-64">
    <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px max-lg:hwp-px-0">
      <div  class="publication-info" data-component-name="publication-info">
  <div class="publication-info__image">
          
      </div>
  <div class="publication-info__text">
    <h4 class="h4 hwp-mb-8">Publication information:</h4>
    <div class="publication-info__body">
      <div class="bibcite-citation">
      <div class="csl-bib-body"><div class="csl-entry"><div class="csl-left-margin">Sperotto F, GutiÃ©rrez-SacristÃ¡n A, Makwana S, Li X, Rofeberg VN, Cai T, Bourgeois FT, Omenn GS, Hanauer DA, Saez C, Bonzel CL, Bucholz E, Dionne A, Elias MD, GarcÃ­a-Barrio N, GonzÃ¡lez TG, Issitt RW, Kernan KF, Laird-Gion J, Maidlow SE, Mandl KD, Ahooyi TM, Moraleda C, Morris M, Moshal KL, Pedrera-JimÃ©nez M, Shah MA, South AM, Spiridou A, Taylor DM, Verdy G, Visweswaran S, Wang X, Xia Z, Zachariasse JM, EHR C for CC of C 19 by, Newburger JW, Avillach P.       <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-pt-32 hwp-pb-64 md:hwp-py-64">
      <div  class="hwp-citations-group">
      <h3 class="h3 hwp-mb-24">Abstract</h3>
  
  <div class="hwp-citations-group__inner">
                  


<div  class="hwp-citation hwp-citation--text-trim hwp-bg-light-base js-hwp-citation" data-component-name="citation">
  <div class="hwp-citation__text">
    <div class="hwp-text-block__default-text">
      <p><b>BACKGROUND: </b>Multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C) is a severe complication of SARS-CoV-2 infection. It remains unclear how MIS-C phenotypes vary across SARS-CoV-2 variants. We aimed to investigate clinical characteristics and outcomes of MIS-C across SARS-CoV-2 eras.</p><p><b>METHODS: </b>We performed a multicentre observational retrospective study including seven paediatric hospitals in four countries (France, Spain, U.K., and U.S.). All consecutive confirmed patients with MIS-C hospitalised between February 1st, 2020, and May 31st, 2022, were included. Electronic Health Records (EHR) data were used to calculate pooled risk differences (RD) and effect sizes (ES) at site level, using  as reference. Meta-analysis was used to pool data across sites.</p><p><b>FINDINGS: </b>Of 598 patients with MIS-C (61% male, 39% female; mean age 9.7 years [SD 4.5]), 383 (64%) were admitted in the  era, 111 (19%) in the  era, and 104 (17%) in the  era. Compared with patients admitted in the  era, those admitted in the  era were younger (ESÂ -1.18 years [95% CIÂ -2.05,Â -0.32]), had fewer respiratory symptoms (RDÂ -0.15 [95% CIÂ -0.33,Â -0.04]), less frequent non-cardiogenic shock or systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) (RDÂ -0.35 [95% CIÂ -0.64,Â -0.07]), lower lymphocyte count (ESÂ -0.16Â ÃÂ 10/uL [95% CIÂ -0.30,Â -0.01]), lower C-reactive protein (ESÂ -28.5Â mg/L [95% CIÂ -46.3,Â -10.7]), and lower troponin (ESÂ -0.14Â ng/mL [95% CIÂ -0.26,Â -0.03]). Patients admitted in the  versus  eras were younger (ESÂ -1.6 years [95% CIÂ -2.5,Â -0.8]), had less frequent SIRS (RDÂ -0.18 [95% CIÂ -0.30,Â -0.05]), lower lymphocyte count (ESÂ -0.39Â ÃÂ 10/uL [95% CIÂ -0.52,Â -0.25]), lower troponin (ESÂ -0.16Â ng/mL [95% CIÂ -0.30,Â -0.01]) and less frequently received anticoagulation therapy (RDÂ -0.19 [95% CIÂ -0.37,Â -0.04]). Length of hospitalization was shorter in the  versus  eras (-1.3 days [95% CIÂ -2.3,Â -0.4]).</p><p><b>INTERPRETATION: </b>Our study suggested that MIS-C clinical phenotypes varied across SARS-CoV-2 eras, with patients in  and  eras being younger and less sick. EHR data can be effectively leveraged to identify rare complications of pandemic diseases and their variation over time.</p><p><b>FUNDING: </b>None.</p>
    </div>

    <div class="hwp-text-block">
      <p><b>BACKGROUND: </b>Multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C) is a severe complication of SARS-CoV-2 infection. It remains unclear how MIS-C phenotypes vary across SARS-CoV-2 variants. We aimed to investigate clinical characteristics and outcomes of MIS-C across SARS-CoV-2 eras.</p><p><b>METHODS: </b>We performed a multicentre observational retrospective study including seven paediatric hospitals in four countries (France, Spain, U.K., and U.S.). All consecutive confirmed patients with MIS-C hospitalised between February 1st, 2020, and May 31st, 2022, were included. Electronic Health Records (EHR) data were used to calculate pooled risk differences (RD) and effect sizes (ES) at site level, using  as reference. Meta-analysis was used to pool data across sites.</p><p><b>FINDINGS: </b>Of 598 patients with MIS-C (61% male, 39% female; mean age 9.7 years [SD 4.5]), 383 (64%) were admitted in the  era, 111 (19%) in the  era, and 104 (17%) in the  era. Compared with patients admitted in the  era, those admitted in the  era were younger (ESÂ -1.18 years [95% CIÂ -2.05,Â -0.32]), had fewer respiratory symptoms (RDÂ -0.15 [95% CIÂ -0.33,Â -0.04]), less frequent non-cardiogenic shock or systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) (RDÂ -0.35 [95% CIÂ -0.64,Â -0.07]), lower lymphocyte count (ESÂ -0.16Â ÃÂ 10/uL [95% CIÂ -0.30,Â -0.01]), lower C-reactive protein (ESÂ -28.5Â mg/L [95% CIÂ -46.3,Â -10.7]), and lower troponin (ESÂ -0.14Â ng/mL [95% CIÂ -0.26,Â -0.03]). Patients admitted in the  versus  eras were younger (ESÂ -1.6 years [95% CIÂ -2.5,Â -0.8]), had less frequent SIRS (RDÂ -0.18 [95% CIÂ -0.30,Â -0.05]), lower lymphocyte count (ESÂ -0.39Â ÃÂ 10/uL [95% CIÂ -0.52,Â -0.25]), lower troponin (ESÂ -0.16Â ng/mL [95% CIÂ -0.30,Â -0.01]) and less frequently received anticoagulation therapy (RDÂ -0.19 [95% CIÂ -0.37,Â -0.04]). Length of hospitalization was shorter in the  versus  eras (-1.3 days [95% CIÂ -2.3,Â -0.4]).</p><p><b>INTERPRETATION: </b>Our study suggested that MIS-C clinical phenotypes varied across SARS-CoV-2 eras, with patients in  and  eras being younger and less sick. EHR data can be effectively leveraged to identify rare complications of pandemic diseases and their variation over time.</p><p><b>FUNDING: </b>None.</p>
    </div>
  </div>

      <ul class="hwp-citation__ctas">
              <li class="expand-button-wrap">
          <button
            class="hwp-text-link hwp-text-link--icon-left hwp-citation__full-body-expand js-hwp-citation__full-body-expand"
            aria-expanded="false"
            aria-controls="hwp-citation-body-content-443299305"
          >
            <span class="material-icon material-icon--show" aria-hidden="true">add_circle</span>

            <span class="material-icon material-icon--hide" aria-hidden="true">do_not_disturb_on</span>
            <span class="hwp-text-link__text">Abstract</span>
          </button>
        </li>
      
          </ul>
  
  </div>
            </div>
</div>

      <hr class="hwp-text-button-light-secondary hwp-mt-32"/>
    </div>

  <main lang="en" id="main-content" role="main" aria-labelledby="page-title" tabindex="-1">
    <div class="layout-content">
        <div>
    <div data-drupal-messages-fallback class="hidden"></div>


<div class="biblio-details">
  <div  lang="en" class="hwp-page-title bibcite-reference">
  <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
    
    <h1 class="text-large" >
      Contraceptive content shared on social media: an analysis of Twitter.
    </h1>
    
     </div>
</div>

  <div class="md:hwp-pt-64">
    <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px max-lg:hwp-px-0">
      <div  class="publication-info" data-component-name="publication-info">
  <div class="publication-info__image">
          
      </div>
  <div class="publication-info__text">
    <h4 class="h4 hwp-mb-8">Publication information:</h4>
    <div class="publication-info__body">
      <div class="bibcite-citation">
      <div class="csl-bib-body"><div class="csl-entry"><div class="csl-left-margin">Huang M, GutiÃ©rrez-SacristÃ¡n A, Janiak E, Young K, Starosta A, Blanton K, Azhir A, Goldfarb CN, Kuperwasser F, Schaefer KM, Stoddard RE, Vatsa R, Merz-Herrala AA, Bartz D. Contraceptive content shared on social media: an analysis of Twitter.</div><div class="csl-right-inline">Contraception and reproductive medicine. 2024;9(1):5. PMID: 38321582</div></div></div>
  </div>

    </div>
    <ul class="publication-info__actions">
              <li>
          <div class="button-dropdown" data-component-name="button-dropdown">
  




<button
   class="hwp-text-link hwp-text-link--icon-left"
    id="publication_citation_download">
  <span class="material-icon" aria-hidden="true">download_for_offline</span>
<span class="hwp-text-link__text">Download citation</span>
</button>

  
  <ul class="button-dropdown__items" role="menu" aria-labelledby="publication_citation_download">
          <li role="menuitem">
        <a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773946&amp;format=bibtex">BibTeX</a>
      </li>
          <li role="menuitem">
        <a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773946&amp;format=endnote8">EndNote X3 XML</a>
      </li>
          <li role="menuitem">
        <a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773946&amp;format=endnote7">EndNote 7 XML</a>
      </li>
          <li role="menuitem">
        <a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773946&amp;format=tagged">Endnote tagged</a>
      </li>
          <li role="menuitem">
        <a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773946&amp;format=marc">Marc</a>
      </li>
          <li role="menuitem">
        <a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773946&amp;format=pubmed_id">PubMedId</a>
      </li>
          <li role="menuitem">
        <a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773946&amp;format=ris">RIS</a>
      </li>
      </ul>
</div>
        </li>
                </ul>
  </div>
</div>
    </div>
  </div>

      <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-pt-32 hwp-pb-64 md:hwp-py-64">
      <div  class="hwp-citations-group">
      <h3 class="h3 hwp-mb-24">Abstract</h3>
  
  <div class="hwp-citations-group__inner">
                  


<div  class="hwp-citation hwp-citation--text-trim hwp-bg-light-base js-hwp-citation" data-component-name="citation">
  <div class="hwp-citation__text">
    <div class="hwp-text-block__default-text">
      <p><b>BACKGROUND: </b>Information on social media may affect peoples' contraceptive decision making. We performed an exploratory analysis of contraceptive content on Twitter (recently renamed X), a popular social media platform.</p><p><b>METHODS: </b>We selected a random subset of 1% of publicly available, English-language tweets related to reversible, prescription contraceptive methods posted between January 2014 and December 2019. We oversampled tweets for the contraceptive patch to ensure at least 200 tweets per method. To create the codebook, we identified common themes specific to tweet content topics, tweet sources, and tweets soliciting information or providing advice. All posts were coded by two team members, and differences were adjudicated by a third reviewer. Descriptive analyses were reported with accompanying qualitative findings.</p><p><b>RESULTS: </b>During the study period, 457,369 tweets about reversible contraceptive methods were published, with a random sample of 4,434 tweets used for final analysis. Tweets most frequently discussed contraceptive method decision-making (26.7%) and side effects (20.5%), particularly for long-acting reversible contraceptive methods and the depot medroxyprogesterone acetate shot. Tweets about logistics of use or adherence were common for short-acting reversible contraceptives. Tweets were frequently posted by contraceptive consumers (50.6%). A small proportion of tweets explicitly requested information (6.2%) or provided advice (4.2%).</p><p><b>CONCLUSIONS: </b>Clinicians should be aware that individuals are exposed to information through Twitter that may affect contraceptive perceptions and decision making, particularly regarding long-acting reversible contraceptives. Social media is a valuable source for studying contraceptive beliefs missing in traditional health research and may be used by professionals to disseminate accurate contraceptive information.</p>
    </div>

    <div class="hwp-text-block">
      <p><b>BACKGROUND: </b>Information on social media may affect peoples' contraceptive decision making. We performed an exploratory analysis of contraceptive content on Twitter (recently renamed X), a popular social media platform.</p><p><b>METHODS: </b>We selected a random subset of 1% of publicly available, English-language tweets related to reversible, prescription contraceptive methods posted between January 2014 and December 2019. We oversampled tweets for the contraceptive patch to ensure at least 200 tweets per method. To create the codebook, we identified common themes specific to tweet content topics, tweet sources, and tweets soliciting information or providing advice. All posts were coded by two team members, and differences were adjudicated by a third reviewer. Descriptive analyses were reported with accompanying qualitative findings.</p><p><b>RESULTS: </b>During the study period, 457,369 tweets about reversible contraceptive methods were published, with a random sample of 4,434 tweets used for final analysis. Tweets most frequently discussed contraceptive method decision-making (26.7%) and side effects (20.5%), particularly for long-acting reversible contraceptive methods and the depot medroxyprogesterone acetate shot. Tweets about logistics of use or adherence were common for short-acting reversible contraceptives. Tweets were frequently posted by contraceptive consumers (50.6%). A small proportion of tweets explicitly requested information (6.2%) or provided advice (4.2%).</p><p><b>CONCLUSIONS: </b>Clinicians should be aware that individuals are exposed to information through Twitter that may affect contraceptive perceptions and decision making, particularly regarding long-acting reversible contraceptives. Social media is a valuable source for studying contraceptive beliefs missing in traditional health research and may be used by professionals to disseminate accurate contraceptive information.</p>
    </div>
  </div>

      <ul class="hwp-citation__ctas">
              <li class="expand-button-wrap">
          <button
            class="hwp-text-link hwp-text-link--icon-left hwp-citation__full-body-expand js-hwp-citation__full-body-expand"
            aria-expanded="false"
            aria-controls="hwp-citation-body-content-2096064225"
          >
            <span class="material-icon material-icon--show" aria-hidden="true">add_circle</span>

            <span class="material-icon material-icon--hide" aria-hidden="true">do_not_disturb_on</span>
            <span class="hwp-text-link__text">Abstract</span>
          </button>
        </li>
      
          </ul>
  
  </div>
            </div>
</div>

<div class="biblio-details">
  <div  lang="en" class="hwp-page-title bibcite-reference">
  <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
    
    <h1 class="text-large" >
      Development and validation of an open-source pipeline for automatic population of case report forms from electronic health records: a pediatric multi-center prospective study.
    </h1>
    
     </div>
</div>

  <div class="md:hwp-pt-64">
    <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px max-lg:hwp-px-0">
      <div  class="publication-info" data-component-name="publication-info">
  <div class="publication-info__image">
          
      </div>
  <div class="publication-info__text">
    <h4 class="h4 hwp-mb-8">Publication information:</h4>
    <div class="publication-info__body">
      <div class="bibcite-citation">
      <div class="csl-bib-body"><div class="csl-entry"><div class="csl-left-margin">GutiÃ©rrez-SacristÃ¡n A, Makwana S, Dionne A, Mahanta S, Dyer KJ, Serrano F, Watrin C, Pages P, Mousavi S, Degala A, Lyons J, Pillion D, Zachariasse JM, Shekerdemian LS, Truong DT, Newburger JW, Avillach P. Development and validation of an open-source pipeline for automatic population of case report forms from electronic health records: a pediatric multi-center prospective study.</div><div class="csl-right-inline">EBioMedicine. 2024;108:105337. PMID: 39288532</div></div></div>
  </div>

    </div>
    <ul class="publication-info__actions">
              <li>
          <div class="button-dropdown" data-component-name="button-dropdown">
  




<button
   class="hwp-text-link hwp-text-link--icon-left"
    id="publication_citation_download">

</button>

  
  <ul class="button-dropdown__items" role="menu" aria-labelledby="publication_citation_download">
          <li role="menuitem">
        <a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773906&amp;format=bibtex">BibTeX</a>
      </li>
          <li role="menuitem">
        <a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773906&amp;format=endnote8">EndNote X3 XML</a>
      </li>
          <li role="menuitem">
        <a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773906&amp;format=endnote7">EndNote 7 XML</a>

      </li>
          <li role="menuitem">
        <a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773906&amp;format=ris">RIS</a>
      </li>
      </ul>
</div>
        </li>
                </ul>
  </div>
</div>
    </div>
  </div>

      <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-pt-32 hwp-pb-64 md:hwp-py-64">
      <div  class="hwp-citations-group">
      <h3 class="h3 hwp-mb-24">Abstract</h3>
  
  <div class="hwp-citations-group__inner">
                  


<div  class="hwp-citation hwp-citation--text-trim hwp-bg-light-base js-hwp-citation" data-component-name="citation">
  <div class="hwp-citation__text">
    <div class="hwp-text-block__default-text">
      <p><b>BACKGROUND: </b>Clinical trials and registry studies are essential for advancing research and developing novel treatments. However, these studies rely on manual entry of thousands of variables for each patient. Repurposing real-world data can significantly simplify the data collection, reduce transcription errors, and make the data entry process more efficient, consistent, and cost-effective.</p><p><b>METHODS: </b>We developed an open-source computational pipeline to collect laboratory and medication information from the electronic health record (EHR) data and populate case report forms. The pipeline was developed and validated with data from two independent pediatric hospitals in the US as part of the Long-terM OUtcomes after Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome In Children (MUSIC) study. Our pipeline allowed the completion of two of the most time-consuming forms. We compared automatically extracted results with manually entered values in one hospital and applied the pipeline to a second hospital, where the output served as the primary data source for case report forms.</p><p><b>FINDINGS: </b>We extracted and populated 51,845 laboratory and 4913 medication values for 159 patients in two hospitals participating in a prospective pediatric study. We evaluated pipeline performance against data for 104 patients manually entered by clinicians in one of the hospitals. The highest concordance was found during patient hospitalization, with 91.59% of the automatically extracted laboratory and medication values corresponding with the manually entered values. In addition to the successfully populated values, we identified an additional 13,396 laboratory and 567 medication values of interest for the study.</p><p><b>INTERPRETATION: </b>The automatic data entry of laboratory and medication values during admission is feasible and has a high concordance with the manually entered data. By implementing this proof of concept, we demonstrate the quality of automatic data extraction and highlight the potential of secondary use of EHR data to advance medical science by improving data entry efficiency and expediting clinical research.</p><p><b>FUNDING: </b>NIH Grant 1OT3HL147154-01, U24HL135691, UG1HL135685.</p>
    </div>

    <div class="hwp-text-block">
      <p><b>BACKGROUND: </b>Clinical trials and registry studies are essential for advancing research and developing novel treatments. However, these studies rely on manual entry of thousands of variables for each patient. Repurposing real-world data can significantly simplify the data collection, reduce transcription errors, and make the data entry process more efficient, consistent, and cost-effective.</p><p><b>METHODS: </b>We developed an open-source computational pipeline to collect laboratory and medication information from the electronic health record (EHR) data and populate case report forms. The pipeline was developed and validated with data from two independent pediatric hospitals in the US as part of the Long-terM OUtcomes after Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome In Children (MUSIC) study. Our pipeline allowed the completion of two of the most time-consuming forms. We compared automatically extracted results with manually entered values in one hospital and applied the pipeline to a second hospital, where the output served as the primary data source for case report forms.</p><p><b>FINDINGS: </b>We extracted and populated 51,845 laboratory and 4913 medication values for 159 patients in two hospitals participating in a prospective pediatric study. We evaluated pipeline performance against data for 104 patients manually entered by clinicians in one of the hospitals. The highest concordance was found during patient hospitalization, with 91.59% of the automatically extracted laboratory and medication values corresponding with the manually entered values. In addition to the successfully populated values, we identified an additional 13,396 laboratory and 567 medication values of interest for the study.</p><p><b>INTERPRETATION: </b>The automatic data entry of laboratory and medication values during admission is feasible and has a high concordance with the manually entered data. By implementing this proof of concept, we demonstrate the quality of automatic data extraction and highlight the potential of secondary use of EHR data to advance medical science by improving data entry efficiency and expediting clinical research.</p><p><b>FUNDING: </b>NIH Grant 1OT3HL147154-01, U24HL135691, UG1HL135685.</p>
    </div>
  </div>

  <ul class="button-dropdown__items" role="menu" aria-labelledby="publication_citation_download">
          <li role="menuitem">
        <a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773751&amp;format=bibtex">BibTeX</a>
      </li>
          <li role="menuitem">
        <a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773751&amp;format=endnote8">EndNote X3 XML</a>
      </li>
          <li role="menuitem">
        <a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773751&amp;format=endnote7">EndNote 7 XML</a>
      </li>
          <li role="menuitem">
        <a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773751&amp;format=tagged">Endnote tagged</a>
      </li>
          <li role="menuitem">
        <a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773751&amp;format=marc">Marc</a>
      </li>
          <li role="menuitem">
        <a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773751&amp;format=pubmed_id">PubMedId</a>
      </li>
          <li role="menuitem">
        <a class="analytics-cta" href="/bibcite/export?content_filter%5B0%5D=1773751&amp;format=ris">RIS</a>
      </li>
      </ul>
</div>
        </li>
                </ul>
  </div>
</div>
    </div>
  </div>

      <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-pt-32 hwp-pb-64 md:hwp-py-64">
      <div  class="hwp-citations-group">
      <h3 class="h3 hwp-mb-24">Abstract</h3>
  
  <div class="hwp-citations-group__inner">
                  


<div  class="hwp-citation hwp-citation--text-trim hwp-bg-light-base js-hwp-citation" data-component-name="citation">
  <div class="hwp-citation__text">
    <div class="hwp-text-block__default-text">
      <p>The Human Phenotype Ontology (HPO) is a widely used resource that comprehensively organizes and defines the phenotypic features of human disease, enabling computational inference and supporting genomic and phenotypic analyses through semantic similarity and machine learning algorithms. The HPO has widespread applications in clinical diagnostics and translational research, including genomic diagnostics, gene-disease discovery, and cohort analytics. In recent years, groups around the world have developed translations of the HPO from English to other languages, and the HPO browser has been internationalized, allowing users to view HPO term labels and in many cases synonyms and definitions in ten languages in addition to English. Since our last report, a total of 2239 new HPO terms and 49235 new HPO annotations were developed, many in collaboration with external groups in the fields of psychiatry, arthrogryposis, immunologyÂ and cardiology. The Medical Action Ontology (MAxO) is a new effort to model treatments and other measures taken for clinical management. Finally, the HPO consortium is contributing to efforts to integrate the HPO and the GA4GH Phenopacket Schema into electronic health records (EHRs) with the goal of more standardized and computable integration of rare disease data in EHRs.</p>
    </div>

    <div class="hwp-text-block">
      <p>The Human Phenotype Ontology (HPO) is a widely used resource that comprehensively organizes and defines the phenotypic features of human disease, enabling computational inference and supporting genomic and phenotypic analyses through semantic similarity and machine learning algorithms. The HPO has widespread applications in clinical diagnostics and translational research, including genomic diagnostics, gene-disease discovery, and cohort analytics. In recent years, groups around the world have developed translations of the HPO from English to other languages, and the HPO browser has been internationalized, allowing users to view HPO term labels and in many cases synonyms and definitions in ten languages in addition to English. Since our last report, a total of 2239 new HPO terms and 49235 new HPO annotations were developed, many in collaboration with external groups in the fields of psychiatry, arthrogryposis, immunologyÂ and cardiology. The Medical Action Ontology (MAxO) is a new effort to model treatments and other measures taken for clinical management. Finally, the HPO consortium is contributing to efforts to integrate the HPO and the GA4GH Phenopacket Schema into electronic health records (EHRs) with the goal of more standardized and computable integration of rare disease data in EHRs.</p>
    </div>
  </div>

      <ul class="hwp-citation__ctas">
              <li class="expand-button-wrap">
          <button
            class="hwp-text-link hwp-text-link--icon-left hwp-citation__full-body-expand js-hwp-citation__full-body-expand"
            aria-expanded="false"
            aria-controls="hwp-citation-body-content-628850618"
          >
            <span class="material-icon material-icon--show" aria-hidden="true">add_circle</span>

            <span class="material-icon material-icon--hide" aria-hidden="true">do_not_disturb_on</span>
            <span class="hwp-text-link__text">Abstract</span>
          </button>
        </li>
      
          </ul>
  
  </div>
            </div>
</div>

      <hr class="hwp-text-button-light-secondary hwp-mt-32"/>

  <main lang="en" id="main-content" role="main" aria-labelledby="page-title" tabindex="-1">
    <div class="layout-content">
